reviewText:
Morphopolis is a game about bugs, some of the smallest creatures in the world and they are rather fascinating and very important to our environment aswell.

This game is a point and click game with puzzles to solve and hidden objects to discover and find, this will help the small bug on its journey of life. This is a very pretty and colourful game, and not very difficult to play.

Also you must complete each chapter, if you decide to stop halfway through you will have to start from the beginning of that chapter, as there is no exit feature while in a level so I just completed them and exited the game afterwards.

Morphopolis is a very short game and the achievements are easy to earn. I found the last puzzle rather challenging, but I managed to solve it and get 100% achievements :)

I have enjoyed my time playing with the bugs and admiring the lovely art and colours, thankyou for this lovely gift. ;D

reviewText:
I played through the whole game, but I can't really recommend it. It was maybe 2 hours or so long, but I spent most of that time feeling frustrated and unrewarded. It is a very simple point-and-click game, only they somehow made the controls of a point-and-click game frustrating - you have to hold down your click to move, and the bug would frequently start spinning around when they'd reach a certain point along the path, and you have to figure out where you can click to get him moving again.

The hidden object part of the game is incredibly simple, and also somewhat frustrating - I know you're going to make me collect the floating orange balls, but I can't do so until I slowly move across several screens to find the thing that is going to need them. Lots of backtracking for no reason. No real rhyme or reason as to why doing a given gathering task ended with the results it did. I also wasn't really sure the game ended, until I saw that I had all of the achievements.

The music is excellent, the art is nice, but in the end - I got the game on a huge sale, and only spent 2 hours playing it, and I wish I hadn't done so. Credit to the creators for trying something different, but it didn't work for me.

reviewText:
MORPHOPOLIS is a gorgeous-looking, casual slow-burn puzzler fueled by hidden object elements; one that I recommend with the caveat that it will certainly not be for everyone.  While not brutally difficult, it is a sometimes frustrating experience that it is well-suited for the casual puzzle and artistic game fan.   There is little direction; and the lack of the ability to save while in the middle of one of MORPHOPOLIS' five beautiful segments is rough, as the inherent beauty of this game is it's calm, wickedly slow movement and it's mesmerizing artwork.  So failing to finish a segment during a sitting results in the dreaded do-over, with your ever-morphing insect ponderously revisiting the beautiful yet limited screens.

That said, the episodes are fairly short, and the game can be finished in a short span (as short as 90 minutes), with all achievements.  But there is the rub; this is not a game you speed through; it is one you savor.  And for someone like myself who's immersion is often limited to nights and weekends by work exhaustion or time constraints, I thoroughly enjoyed playing through the various trials of our weary bug, as a calming cool down for the brain if you will... Though the puzzles vary from fairly difficult to rather simple, puzzle veterans may have a leg up on recognizing what it is you are supposed to actually do.  There is zero direction... but hit the discussion board for the concept, and off you go.  Only other minor fret was that in some cases, the hidden object items you are required to collect are quite difficult to discern and at times don't really resemble what you need to find; and I am not hot on clicking randomly as a strategy.

Still, for what it is, MORPHOPOLIS succeeds in being an engrossing, beautiful, casual, albeit short experience that is worth a go if you want to step away from the bullet hell for a moment.  If you enjoy it for what it is, you are bound to be rewarded with a fun little puzzler that is certainly like no other...

reviewText:
Nice as an art gallery, but awful as a game.
The bugs move reeeeaally slowly. I know how fast bugs move in real life. I have seen them. Why do they move so slowly here? There's no reason other than to draw out the gameplay way longer than it needs to be.
The game isn't very good at letting you know what you can and can't do. The only way to move is to hold your mouse down in the direction you want to go, but you can only go along preset paths, and some of the screens are in places that don't even look like paths and feel like you'd only ever find them on accident.
It's basically a glorified hidden object game, except everything is so vibrant that the stuff you have to pick out doesn't tend to stand out enough. There were a few instances where I wasn't even sure what exactly I was looking for.
The minigames are generally alright, though there's two that are abnormally challenging compared to the rest of the game. The flower bud puzzle especially, which is painful both because of the puzzle itself and the fiddly controls.
It's very short. 5 small levels". No real connecting story except that you play as the creature you helped in the previous level
date: and at the end you open a door and then the screen just fades out. Abrupt.\nThe game looks very pretty and sounds pretty nice too
hoursPlayed: but it's slow and frustrating for what should be a relaxing experience
voteText: and not worth the money for what little gameplay is given to the player."

reviewText:
Verdict: Take a peek at the posted screenshots to enjoy the hand drawn art if that is what drew you to this, no need to buy and play the game for that. The 'game', as implemented, is an exercise in frustration.

Positive:
- Cute hand drawn graphics.
- It's different, stands out in used art and 'delivery' of the puzzles.
- At 95% off, really cheap.

Negative:
- Total lack of graphics/sound/control settings (why do people keep doing this for PC games?)
- Zero instructions, tutorial or guidance, so just click around and watch what happens and see if you can figure out what the devs were thinking at the time.
- 5 levels total, with 1-4 hidden object puzzles each, some of which have additional puzzles after. Again, zero instructions so just click stuff and maybe you'll see something happen that will give you a clue about what's expected of you.
- Level puzzles are spread out over several screens, so you have to make your bug crawl around, with regular backtracking required. Excruciatingly slow method of scrolling between level screens, and no way to speed it up.
- There is not even a hint at what paths your bug can even take. No arrows, no clearly different coloured or constructed pathways, nothing. Just click the screen edges at different spots and wait to see how far the bug will crawl and maybe by the time it gets there it'll scroll the screen and hey, now you know. Or click a different spot and wait some more.
- No save/load options. It will remember a level as fully finished, but leaving a level unfinished forces you to restart all the puzzles you already solved on that level.
- Even with all that, it's an extremely short game. I fully finished it in under 3 hours, of which almost half was spent just clicking randomly and most of the other half waiting for the bugs to crawl to scroll the screen, and only a fraction actually doing any puzzle solving.


I can understand trying to do things different from all the others. I can understand trying to be artsy. I can understand trying to minimize user interface and controls.

But for the love of all that is good and right in PC gaming, please never let any of that prevent you from implementing the required basics:
- PC's are not a standard environment, and PC users are used to having pretty detailed control. A settings dialog allowing to change graphics/sound/controls is a must on the PC platform.
- Some basic instructions about controls, method and goal of the game. Random clicking to see what happens is not 'learning to play', it's just plain annoying.
- Save/load/checkpoint mechanics, especially in a game that makes one waste a lot of time just getting around on a level.

Sorry, but even at pennies, I can't recommend this as a game. Cute art style though, so check out the screenshots.

reviewText:
Morphopolis may be one of the most beautiful games I've played this year, but its remarkable looks aren‚Äôt always backed up by strong puzzle design. Taking on the role of a caterpillar as it undergoes five metamorphoses into ever larger insects, you‚Äôll find hidden objects and solve puzzling minigames across more than a dozen scenes ‚Äî each as lusciously detailed as the last ‚Äî all backed by a stellar soundtrack amidst a bare-bones interface.
Feeling somewhat like Machinarium meets The Tiny Bang Story, Morphopolis has you walking your insect between scenes. Each location holds one or more obstacles that can only be overcome after you collect all the objects it‚Äôs missing. Sometimes that leads to the obstacle simply moving out of the way; other times, you must complete a minigame or puzzle. Most of these are fairly straightforward, though trial and error is necessary as there‚Äôs no guidance, and a few prove confounding, especially given the limited feedback on offer.
Astounding presentation and imaginative world designs are what set Morphopolis apart. Each scene is akin to a painting come to life, hand-illustrated in gorgeous watercolor hues and pencil-sketch precision, and the world seems to grow and alter in perspective as your parasitic critter inhabits larger hosts. All the while, multi-layered and earthy ambient music sets a laid-back tone that perfectly suits the dawdling pace and relaxing mechanics of the adventure.
The problem is that it‚Äôs set back by puzzles that alternate between overly simplistic and too opaque, encouraging experimentation without providing enough feedback with which to gauge how your interactions affect the system. Morphopolis ultimately relies too strongly on its looks to get by with a relatively weak design.
The astonishing illustrations, excellent soundtrack, and delightful world of Morphopolis may be worth the price of admission alone in what is an otherwise middling hidden-object game.

reviewText:
Morphopolis takes you through the insect world. Discover their true beauty and the adventure through the life of insects...

I got this game for $0.29 NZD on sale,

Morphopolis is a point and click game. One fascinating game to play, discovering their life and beauty of the insects through Morphopolis.
Morphopolis is a game where you have to solve puzzles and clicking on hidden objects. Looking at the artwork, it grabs alot of attention to your eyes because of how they used the colours in a fascinating insect world. Very colourful, you really do discover the beauty of the tiny world underneath our feet. The game has such relaxing music, it helps you concentrate on the game, very soothing music.

You start as a specific insect, you need to find all the hidden objects because they are the keys to unlock the puzzle. Once you solved the puzzle, you will continue onto a new chapter with a new bug. Every chapter, there are new insects. There are new hidden objects and keys for new insects and chapters, and the puzzles do get harder and I do find it quite difficult. Hidden objects are usually camoflaged into the colourful background. But the game isn't really that hard. All achievements are easy to unlock as most are just solving the puzzles. One negative thing is that  there is no exit chapter feature, which leaves you hanging in the game or try solving it. Also there is no save button, which if you exit you would have to start again.

This game is very short and simple game, intriguing artwork and colours used to represent the insect world.

8/10

reviewText:
I've played for two hours and that was actually enough to complete the game. I thought the premise of embarking on a 'parasitic crusade' was amusing, that is actually kind of what you do in this. I really liked it.
- Yes, it's quite short and a mobile port which might put some people off
- But it has a variety of puzzles which I found unique, interesting and challenging

http://youtu.be/yNosN7BgjTQ
http://youtu.be/5lgMkRih1TY
The first level is quite simple you just have to find objects such as leaves and little yellow balls, complete a puzzle and use the stuff you find to complete the stage. Each level is basically like this but they gradually become larger and more complex.
-----Each stage you take a new form. Each level ends with you resurrecting and taking taking control of a new and larger insect i.e. you burrow your little aphid grub into the head of a grasshopper then in the next stage you are in the form of that grasshopper, then a bee and so on.
-----Yeah finding a certain amount of specific objects scattered and hidden randomly throughout each stage sounds kind of mundane. But I enjoyed that kind of activity, it's kind of like Where's Wally. It was sometimes challenging to track the last few objects.
-----Interspersed throughout that were the puzzles. I was never able to figure them out straight away. There are no instructions. Sometimes I had to fiddle around to determine what you are meant to do in them, before I could even puzzle my way through them. But once I'd done that and completed each one, I found most them quite satisfying. One of them ended a bit too quickly before it became challenging. That one involved repeating a sequence demonstrated by the illuminating tails of insects, which became increasingly more complex. I think that one should have gone on for longer to really challenge you. That would have been cool because you actually create a kind of melody. Another puzzle was actually a jigsaw puzzle made up of differently shaped moth and butterflies. It was a simple idea, but I really liked that one.

I liked the artwork quite a bit. It made me think of illustrated children's books that I've seen before. The music is really nice and soothing. Your insects dawdle along, you cannot rush around. So it's a slow paced and relaxing game.
-----One thing of note is that this game basically has no options menu. This is probably a lot to do with the fact that it is a mobile port. I used windows volume control to turn sound down, Alt-enter didn't work for toggle fullscreen. So had to maximise the window and use a third party program to force into into a borderless window.

I thought the game was short and sweet. Personally I'm not too worried about paying $8.50 for a two hour game. But obviously that may be considered a good price by everyone in this case. The game didn't really have much of an ending. You are just taken back to the main menu without even being taken shown the credits. Not that I really cared too much. However I think it would pretty cool if the developers add more stages, but I think they'd run out of bigger insect eventually lol

reviewText:
Morphopolis is a gorgeous P&C game bringing you through the life of a bug that morphs into other forms as it completes its journey. Where that journey goes exactly, is not really known, but you will point and click your way through several beautifully designed levels, finding hidden objects to unlock puzzles and continue onto the next stage.

The music is rather relaxing and don't get old too quickly but after a long while, you may just want to mute it and play your own music instead.

The puzzles aren't too hard but will require a bit of your brain to solve.

My biggest gripe is control. As you are controlling your little critter around, sometimes it gets confused or locks up and goes back and forth back and forth cause it doesn't really know what you want. Instead of pointing and clicking and your creature going there, you have to hold it, and not al paths are self-evident.

The game moves at a very slow pace, so if you're not in a realxed mood, don't bother to play it or you might get frustrated with the slow speed. Personally I think the game has no replay value, but for such a cheap game, did you really expect any?

Overall 6/10 - Get it on sale for an interesting mix of art, music and puzzles.

reviewText:
Why do bad things happen to good people? Or why does good art happen to bad games, for that matter? After playing this, I'm even more confused about it than ever.

Morphopolis feels like a blend of a small scale, 2D, point and click adventure, mixed with the weaker elements of an offbeat hidden object game. You'll control an insect as it gathers objects for an array of bugs or plants and occasionally assemble the body parts of other, larger dead bugs so you can occupy its carcass to progress to the next stage. No, really. I didn't make that last part up. I never knew that's how evolution worked, I'm learning things already from this game, which is an unusual exception, given how unwilling it is to teach you anything else at any point.

Aside from a not very helpful cursor appearing at the start to prompt you how to move, there's no other attempt to guide the player in any way. I don't expect a game to hold my hand the whole way through, but surely page one of chapter one of the game design manual should tell you the first thing you do is teach a player the mechanics of your game and how to navigate and interact with it. When you struggle to move from your starting position in a game then you know you're in trouble. And that's a problem that persists the whole way through.

To move you have to point to your desired destination then hold down the left mouse button. The first problem here is understanding where you can even go at any point. You can click on your insect to momentarily summon a trail of green dust around your immediate area and show potential paths, but even this felt surprisingly unhelpful. But even when you do understand where to go, getting there is a task in itself. Movement seems temperamental at best and my bug would frequently appear to get stuck, waggling back and forth while rooted to the spot, or else fail to move at all, requiring repeated attempts before it would eventually go where I wanted it to... slowly. Very, very, slowly. Because, y'know... insects are notorious for being some of the most slow-moving and cumbersome creatures in the animal kingdom. Really, something so fundamental as basic movement and navigation should not be an infuriating obstacle the player should have to constantly wrestle with as part of the game's challenge.

There are a small handful of puzzles added to the mix, but these aren't especially satisfying to complete, and like the rest of the game, no attempt is made to explain them to the player in any way. At one point you control a bee with the ability to hop. It doesn't seem like something important when you discover it, more like a cute little idiosyncrasy, but later in the stage it proves vital for completing a section. I found this purely by accident rather than having it hinted at in any way, and were it not for being in the right place at the right time, I likely would have needed to resort to a guide to complete the game. That kind of methodology to progression just stinks of bad design to me.

It's not a game entirely without its charms, as the sound, look and short play time are its greatest virtues, but when a game's world is more fun to look at and listen to than to actually interact with or inhabit, then you have to ask yourself what's the point?". I'd sooner recommend looking up images or videos of the game and experiencing its finer points that way. Otherwise
date: I'd strongly advice passing over on playing this one yourself."

reviewText:
Morphopolis looks like a weird game. And an unique one. I can definitely tell you that it‚Äôs weird, especially in its art design and storytelling (if you can even call it that), but it‚Äôs not as unique as you would think. The game will feel very familiar to those who‚Äôve played hidden object games before and have taken on a couple of simple puzzles in the past. And once you start playing it‚Äôs really not even that weird. You‚Äôll see.

But Morphopolis isn‚Äôt for just anyone in my opinion. It‚Äôs short with only 5 levels, but it‚Äôs also very slow. The creature you control moves at the slowest pace possible and you unfortunately need him to navigate through the levels.
Not much is explained when you start; a simple gesture to move your mouse from one point to the other is pretty much all it will tell you to do. The rest is up to you.
I like the fact that it doesn‚Äôt hold your hand all the way through, but some of the level designs aren‚Äôt easily navigated and that results in your character getting stuck in parts of the environment or your character not knowing which way to go when you‚Äôre clearly moving your mouse to the right direction.
If we ignore these flaws the gameplay basically comes down to you clicking anywhere on the screen, hoping to unlock new objectives. New objectives can usually be found by clicking on other creatures and it then comes down to finding the requested items. Some of these items are expertly hidden and some of them are way too obvious. If you really can‚Äôt find a certain item you can always ask for a hint; a meter in the upper right corner will refill after you click on it once. After that you can request another hint if you wish. Anyway, it also requires a fair amount of backtracking, but the slow pace keeps it from being (and becoming) any fun.
Sometimes a better, deeper puzzle unlocks after finishing a certain objective. These range from a solitaire-like puzzle to solving a jigsaw puzzle. Around level 4 the difficulty picks up and I must admit I had a hard time solving the puzzles found in level 4 and 5.
A story can be interpreted but isn‚Äôt necessarily there I would say. It‚Äôs about your character growing up I think but please keep in mind that that‚Äôs my very basic interpretation of it all. The game doesn‚Äôt end with credits rolling; it just brings you back to the ‚Äòlevel select‚Äô menu. So I‚Äôm not sure if it‚Äôs even trying to tell a story.

The art direction is phenomenal. I don‚Äôt know what I would call it exactly, but it‚Äôs colorful and full of detail. It‚Äôs definitely worth a look. Sounds are pretty much non-existent and the music on the other hand is pretty good. The game runs in a window that can be resized as you see fit but I‚Äôm not sure if I would recommend it as I had issues solving the music/memory puzzle because of it (or else it‚Äôs just a bug). In any case, the graphics remain sharp, even when the window is maxed out.

Morphopolis is certainly a pretty game. But it‚Äôs not a really fun game. Even though the game isn‚Äôt terribly long I wish it ended sooner. It might be because of the (semi-)casual gameplay, it might be because of the slow pacing, I‚Äôm not really sure. One thing I am sure of however is that I would suggest people to wait for a price drop. The current price is just a tad too high for now.

[Rating: 65/100]

reviewText:
This was a fun little hidden object game with a fresh new style in terms of the genre.

I love the HOG genre of games and anyone else that does has bound to have noticed by now that most of them are pretty standard in terms of story and style. Whether it be an Indiana Jones style treasure hunter, an antiques trader, a supernatural entity or just the classic crime detective, Morphopolis puts an interesting new twist on HOGs.

‚ÄúLose yourself in the mesmerizing, fantastical world of Morphopolis, a game about transformation and discovery.‚Äù

It reminds me a little bit like The Tiny Bang Story, which was another small but unique HOG, in the way the HOG elements are laid out. It‚Äôs more interactive and visual then your standard HOG game. Instead of just being given a list to things to find, you play as a bug, traversing its way across a lucid insect world. You click and drag your mouse to move and although the direction isn‚Äôt entirely clear I think it‚Äôs easy enough to explore and figure things out. You can interact with things around you and figure out what you need to be finding from that.

The gameplay for me was fine. I read a few reviews before I bought the game that suggested the controls and direction of the game was annoying to some seeing as it may have been a port over from touch screen devices. In all honesty, I found it completely fine to control and didn‚Äôt feel that directions were ever necessary. Although on gameplay alone I would say that if you took away the stunning visuals, there wouldn‚Äôt be much too it.

The art in this game is beautiful, especially on a bigger screen. The many different colours and details will keep you interested in what‚Äôs going on. Which is great given the games quite laid back pacing. The visuals in the game definitely make up for the lack of actual gameplay as mentioned above.

With that said, every now and then you get puzzles of which I thought were pretty good. There were a few that I did have to actually think about to solve. The last one especially being the hardest to do.

Overall the game took me just under 2 hours to complete. It‚Äôs a fairly short game but I felt that it was neither too short nor too long, which is always good. It‚Äôs a nice little game to kill a few hours with and also get another 100%ed game.

As far as I am aware, the achievements are purely for completely the game‚Äôs milestones and its puzzles without using hints. So it‚Äôs an easy one to do.

All in all I really liked this game, it was short but sweet and generally a nice little indie game.


TL:DR : An interesting HOG game with a unique new style for the genre. Basic gameplay but beautiful art, which more than makes up for it. Good puzzles, short and easy to 100%. Definitely give it a try.

reviewText:
Very pretty, good music, but very short.  It took me about 75 minutes to go through the whole thing and most of that time was spent backtracking because your bug moves friggin slow and every time you solve one minipuzzle you have to revisit all the scenes for the next mini. (the rest of my hours is idling for card drops)

I was also expecting to learn something about insects along the way.  However, the presentation is fanciful rather than realistic and there was nothing substantive to take away.

The game itself is mostly hidden objects and, mercifully, there's a rechargable hint pointer because some of the objects are very hidden, although that doesn't work in the half dozen instances where you have to guess that clicking your insect in the right spot does something special.  The hidden objects unlock several longer-form puzzles which are a mix of logic and visual matching, all rather easy, some downright trivial, with a couple that will take a few minutes to figure out.  ***Absolutely not solvable if you're color blind as some of them require very subtle color matching.***

5/10.  If you get it on a good sale or in a bundle, it's definitely worth a little dabble for the visuals. Otherwise, it's too short and light to recommend.

reviewText:
Puzzzzling puzzzzle with bugzzzzRating : Ok

Guide your morphed insect in this puzzler game where you have to manipulate and collect stuff to continue to the next screen. Kinda refreshing if you take the art style, scenes and backdrop. No mysteries to solve, horrors to overcome or keys to find. But as with all it gets a bit frustrating when you hit that one screen where you really don't know what to do.

And that's the bit weak side of this game: you are literally thrown into the scenes without the slightest idea what to do. Some screens have hint options, other are deprived of that so you really don't know what to do and how to continue. A bit of experimentation and try-out is then the only thing you can do.

What also bothers me is that the game doesn't have any options other than quit and 'go to main menu'. No settings to alter the music or sounds, no resolution options or even a full screen option.

Other than that I can recommend the game if you like point-and-click discovery games in a slightly different setting than usually. But to call it great great a bit too far.

reviewText:
Morphopolis - a 'maybe' game?This is where I wish Steam's review system offered more than a recommended yes/no option, because saying that this game is recommended implies that the game is more than it is and ignores a couple of frustrations, but saying the game is not recommended does the game an undeserved disservice.  So bear in mind this recommendation is actually a MAYBE, and read on to know whether this is the game for you...

What is it?Morphopolis is a casual and short puzzle/hidden-object game crafted over 5 beautiful levels.  You start life as a small insect and, using point-and-click, must find your way through each level where you will metamorphose into a bigger insect.  If you've played the excellent Machinarium, the gameplay style is very similar (point and click, and find hidden objects) but there is where the similarity ends.  Morphopolis is nowhere near as long as Machinarium, the puzzles are not as challenging nor as varied, and overall the game is very simple to complete, with only the final puzzle offering any greater degree of difficulty.

What's to like?The unique artwork and ambient music are a joy to experience (the visuals are gorgeous), and the lack of hand-holding will be a blessing for gamers who like to work out what they must do.  Every insect and every flower might offer some interaction (or might not) and it's left to you to discover.  Once you uncover an insect or flower that you can interact with, it will have some basic needs to be fulfilled (ie hidden objects - like finding 10 pollen seeds and feeding them to the flower) before it will enable a new pathway for your insect to use (either by unfolding a new branch to climb or unblocking the way to a new area).  Each level will have a final puzzle to solve, which are mostly of average difficulty and very enjoyable (if brief).

The not-so-goodThe lack of hand-holding would be most welcome if only elements that were meant to be interacted with would be a little more responsive.  As it stands, many interactive things need several experimental clicks before they yield (or not), and because there is no clue offered by the interface as to whether an element is interactive or not, you'll be clicking a lot of things to progress.  Navigation was a particular issue, with the player's insect dawdling at an annoyingly slow pace and frequently becoming stuck in areas that weren't actually blocked - especially frustrating given there was a fair bit of back-tracking to do.  There was a lack of variety in solving each stage (outside of the end puzzles) and it became too easy to solve as a result.  Finally, the last level had a disappointing ending: given that my insect successfully metamorphosed through each of the previous 4 stages, I truly expected to metamorphose into some big and beautiful butterfly at the end of the game.  Instead, the game simply faded to black, leaving me wondering whether the game had ended or not.  Because of the game's simplicity, there is no real replay value.

ConclusionMorphopolis is a pleasant diversion from bigger and more challenging games, and it's a piece of art in many ways.  However, it's somewhat let down by its short length without any real ending, frustrating interface and the lack of variety needed to complete each stage and reach the end-of-level puzzle.  I would recommend it in a heartbeat at a sale price, and would also recommend it at its full ¬£3.99 price if you are looking for something pretty and lightweight to play for a short while (especially if you do enjoy games like Machinarium).  Otherwise, there are longer and more challenging games with a little less frustration that might be more worthwhile for you.

reviewText: This game is gorgeous. The art style is unique and that is reason enough in my mind to get it, especially if its on sale. The soundtrack is very calming and helps you not get frustrated with the puzzles. The game is meant to be enjoyed slowly, taking in this interesting world. While I love the look and sounds of the game, I have a couple of nitpicks. With each level, I feel you have to click everything to find the next objective. There is sometimes some confusion about where your little insect is allowed to explore. There is a hint system that keeps the player from frustration. The puzzles are everywhere from easy to frustrating. Whether they are easy will simply depend on the player. With each puzzle you are left to figure it out, without any help or explanation. Also, once you begin a puzzle, there is no way to leave it. If you want to quit, you will have to crash the game. There is no save option, so once you begin the level, be prepared to finish it, or have the game run in the background. I had to walk away from certain puzzles sometimes, but the soundtrack is so calming, I didn't mind hearing it. Despite the nitpicks, this is a wonderful little puzzle game with great visuals.

reviewText:
Short hidden insect game.

Well, technically it's a hidden object game, but in many respects it is different from your typical HOG: here we have hand-drawn art instead of your 3D hodgepodge of object; biological processes instead of a plot with a woman seeking some daughter (not necessarily hers); multi-screen scenes; and collection quests that originate from within the scene.

It feels very relaxing (some might call it slow), leaving you to ponder and puzzle out what you're supposed to be doing. I spent a very pleasant 2 hours doing just that. Some of the puzzles are logical, others are actual puzzles: the most ingenious is the one where you put objects back into the scene (putting parts of a plant back in place), and I wish there more of those.

It's casual, short, very different, looks beautiful, and plays well. Recommended.

This week it is on sale as part of the art appreciation pack"."

reviewText: I was drawn to Morphopolis for the wonderfully unique art-style and the promise of relaxing music and gameplay. Morphopolis delivers on style and audio, but the gameplay swings between calm, maybe even boring, and on the other end of the scale it can be infuriating. If you like hidden object games I'd definitely recommend this, but to most people I would say give it a miss. I'm personally not keen on hidden object games, but I thought I'd give this one a go anyway for a change of pace. Some some of the puzzles in Morphopolis left me without any clue how to interact with them, and I had to resort to Googling to know how to even grasp some basic controls. The most important thing I could have known going into the game is that clicking/tapping on your own bug is something you can (and should) do, which simply didn't occur to me until I read an introduction on how to play the game after becoming stuck, which kind of seems like the sort of thing the game should be guiding you into doing. The most positive thing about this game was that I was able to draw my wife into playing it with me. It works great on a touch screen so we were both able to tap away at the screen together working on puzzles and looking for hidden bugs and junk. It's not a long game, but at the end of it we were glad it was over.\n\n4 out of 10, would not dig around for bugs again. Purdy though.

reviewText: Simple gameplay yet a little challenging in some areas. reviewText:
Short version: 82%Morphopolis is an incredibly short hidden object puzzle game and art showcase, where you control a bug in a series of astonishing, hand-drawn scenes.

Long version:Morphopolis is a simple hidden object game, where the goal is to gather a series of similar items. These items unlock a minigame, another item, or a new screen you can explore.

There is no real story: you control a bug which ends up in a larger body in each chapter, and that‚Äôs about it.
Therefore, the game sells itself with a unique (slightly Moebius-like) art style. This somewhat alien landscape is a marvel to look at, but doesn‚Äôt overstay its welcome: most chapters are barely ten minute long‚Äì even though your movement is incredibly slow. Naturally this means the whole game lasts barely an hour, but if you like this distinct visual style, Morphopolis is an excellent pick.

reviewText:
Hooray! Finally done.

What's Morphopolis?
Morphopolis is puzzle game. This game educates us about transformation (metamorphosis) of the insect. Although this game reminded me about Biology when I was studying at senior high school, I don't know what kind of insect appeared in this game. At least I just remembered one thing, what Lepidoptera[en.wikipedia.org]is.

The gameplay?
In game, you not only see the beauty scenery of nature but also the relaxing music. There are five chapters in order to finish. Each chapter presents the stage of metamorphosis. You have to solve the riddles (finding the things and solving the puzzle) in order going to next stage. You can play this game for short time actually, but it depends how fast you can solve the riddles.

Should I recommend Morphopolis?
Yes, I should. I recommend this game for puzzle and indie game lovers.

If you are not one of them, will you give a chance for Morphopolis, won't you?

Grab the game man! It's cheap too.

P.S.
I would like to say thanks to my friend, Haru Yoshida.
Thank you so much. You're awesome.

reviewText:
In a stayle akin to Machinarium, Morphopolis immediately draws the player in with its beautiful illustrations. The background music is relaxing, and the play style is unhurried.

I particularly enjoyed the immersion aspect, and wished the game was longer. Perhaps new chapters will be released as upgrades (hint hint). The puzzles, are simplistic compared to the gold standard of the Myst/Riven series, but very enjoyable nonetheless.

Initially, I ran into a bug at Level 4, but the devs were lightening quick to respond and equally as quick to fix it. Impressive. They were also very helpful in tactfully pointing out a user error -- mine.

The colors are beautiful, the illustrations transport one into an interesting and inviting world, the music is lovely, the puzzles fun and challenging enough to keep it interesting but not so much so that you need a notebook and a 'bang head here' sign next to your monitor. Great game to enjoy alone, or together with your kiddos who are of an age to enjoy hidden object activities.

Looking forward to more!!

reviewText:
Interesting concept of the game. Hidden object is the most accurate description, but it certainly isn't a standard game from that genre. There is no story and still you can follow the 'plot' pretty easily.

The presentation is unique and the music fits the atmosphere nicely. The animations aren't perfect, but again fit the style of the game very well. The controls aren't that great and guessing where to go and/or how to get there can be a bit frustrating. The controls just work well enough to finish the game, but you will run into some problems with them.

Another small issue is that you have to move between screens and it is awfully slow. It's a design decision to include this 'mechanic' into the game, but I don't think that it works particularly well. Still it only slows the rather short game down, so it's really not much of an issue.

Is the game worth to play? Yes. Is it worth 5$? Well, no. It is quite short and offers no replay value, so get it in a sale or from a bundle. That being said try to get in the next proper sale, as it is a worthwhile experience :)

reviewText:
TL;DR: A casual and pretty short but nice hidden object adventure with a bug theme.

The first thing you notice with Morphopolis is that it is extremely colourful. The screen is full of mesmerizing plants, leaves, branches and bugs. A relaxing string-music is playing on the background. Because of all the colours it is initially difficult to focus: what am I looking at exactly?

It turns out you are a caterpillar. Crawling around (using mouse) feels slow and wonky, but you'll get used to it. A cursor appears and instructs you to crawl and click on objects. Surprise, it's a hidden object game, the casual version of adventure genre! Every one of the five levels has several different things to find, some of which only trigger if you go near them and use your bug magic (by clicking the bug).

Some stuff is difficult to make out of the background while others are very easy to spot. Finding stuff gives you power to influence other bugs or plants. This way you'll open paths to other areas. Your ultimate purpose is to morph into a greater being bug.

Occasionally, once a level or so, a puzzle is triggered. Simple puzzles require arranging seeds in the right order, deducing perfect shapes or rebuilding scenes. Most of them are relaxing and simple enough though a couple of them were even pretty challenging.

Finding stuff can be a pain because of the bright-coloured scenery. Never fear, as mercifully there's an in-game hint system that shows you where the elusive stuff is hiding. True to the casual theme, there's no punishment whatsoever for using it - you just have to wait a bit for it to cool-down to use it again.

Two and half hours later I had completed the game. It was perhaps a little short and scarce on content for the price. Nevertheless, it was a pleasant experience and also a relaxing write, idling in-game waiting for the last couple of card drops and listening to the music. Get Morphopolis if you don't shy away from puzzles but also wish to relax for a single evening.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Very similar to The Tiny Bang Story, and I don't say refer to this as a negative aspect due to the fact that I really enjoyed TTBS. Basically you are an insect and each game's level represents a metamorphosis stage in the bug's life. The art style is amazing in Morphopolis and I really enjoyed it's concept. The gameplay is pretty similar to TTBS where you have to pick up certain items to have the chance to solve a certain puzzle. The hint system is well setup in a way that it cannot be overused and only utilized in a emergency situation. The game itself has 5 stages, and it's about two hours long. The soundtrack is very relaxing. I feel like I should have payed the full price, in order to motivate the developers to make more of this type of games, but instead I purchased Morphopolis for a ridiculous amount of 24 cents... Anyways, I naturally recommend Morphopolis for the point&click gamer.

PS: It's one of those games you get all the achievements simply by beating the game.

reviewText:
A beatifully drawn game with an equally beautiful soundtrack. I can recommend Morphoplis if you are looking for a serene experience of clicking hidden objects and solving puzzles. It is let down somewhat by the slow and clunky movement in the game, but given how simple the gameplay is, I can excuse it. The first time I played it though, I couldn't work out even the basic movement, which is essentially point in a particular direction and hold down the mouse button.

There are only certain paths you can follow through the foliage, and it's soon obvious where these paths are. The learning curve of working out what on earth you are supposed to be doing in this garden somehow adds to the dreamlike quality of the scenery, and there are no textual or spoken cues to stop you thinking like an insect interacting in its natural environment.

You should come to Morphopolis with a relaxed frame of mind, because otherwise you could get easily frustrated. It's the gaming equivalent of getting in touch with nature and living among the flowers. It is a very short, casual game, but leaves its mark on you, showing what else games can be than blood-thirsty war games.

reviewText:
At the time of this review, the game is on sale for $0.19. Quick verdict: get it!

Morphopolis is a hidden object game where you progress by collecting certain quantities of a specific object to fulfill an objective and proceed further in the level. The objects are hidden in the colorful backgrounds and you collect them by clicking on them. There are 5 levels, and aside from item collection, each level has a bug-themed puzzle to solve. Most are bland and predictable, but a couple stood out as creative.

It doesn't do anything out of the ordinary, and is quite short (<2hrs), but on a sale it is a quite enjoyable way to unwind.

Tip: Finding your path can unintiutive. Clicking on your bug sends out green balls towards all possible paths in your proximity.

reviewText:
Never thought I'd describe a game this way, but this game is RELAXING. The music and trippy artwork mixed with the fact that you're playing as a bug does something nice for a tired overworked brain.

This is a mild puzzle game with no real instructions, but don't let that drive you off. It's actually really fun and the music is superb.

You have to find your quests" by clicking on the more interesting pieces of the scenery then once you've found all the required items (it counts down) you click on the completed item bubble and it'll show you "who" to turn it in to.
This aspect of the game is very much like Where's Waldo. You have to look in the background to find your "quest" objects. Some will be easy and some will be tucked away. When your "hero" bug glows green you have to find what else is glowing green and try to sit on it.

It's very short (if you're good at the puzzles about 2 hrs)
date: but worth it if you like Where's Waldo and medium difficulty puzzles.\n\n"

reviewText:
A simple point and click adventure where your goal is to infest a deceased organism larger than yourself. Once you infest the creature you're able to control it and the cycle begins again... as the cycles continue you become the russian nesting doll of parasites... continually collecting resources and infesting more powerful creatures. For what purpose, we may never know, for we are only given a small glimpse into this creature's existence.

I give it two thumbs up with high praise of this game's warning to humanity of the evil to come.

It's adaptable. It can solve complex puzzles. It bends other creatures to it's will. We're the only ones that know it's coming. We must stop it.

reviewText: This is a uniquely beautiful, wordless, hidden object game that focuses on insects.  You guide a variety of insects through five scenarios, collecting body parts and seeds and interacting with other bugs and plants. The movement speed is really slow, but that's the only knock I have. The puzzles are creative and challenging without being overly difficult, and the music, although limited, is very enjoyable.  But the big thing is the graphics - they are very unique in their coloration and style and that makes all the impact.  The game takes a little over an hour for the five scenarios, so it's short but sweet.  Definitely in the category of games as art, with interaction taking a back seat to aesthetics, but still worth the experience.

reviewText:
Morphopolis is a point-and-click adventure game that is both beautiful and unique; However its gameplay is slow,boring, and repetative while being relaxing at the same time. After thirty minutes of gameplay I wanted to stop, I was constantly wondering around playing I-Spy with the game. I would say that around 80% of this game is I-Spy with insanely slow movement. The other 20% is spent doing puzzles which were mostly unique and condusing. Overall I would say to only get this game while it's on sale just to see wheter you like it or not. If at full-price, then there is definitely something better to spend your money on.

~Pros~
+Beautiful Artwork
+Unique Artwork
+Unique Game Concept
+Unique Puzzles
+Casual Players Welcome
+All Achievements Unlocked in only one Playthrough

~Cons~
-No Options
-No Controls
-No Audio
-No Video Options
-Repetative Gameplay
-Repetative Soundtrack
-Two Hours of Gameplay
-Extremely Slow Gameplay
-Buggy Movement
-Zero Turtorial or Instruction
-Confusing Gameplay
-Only Auto-Saves after each chapter
-If you leave during a 45 minute chapter, you must restart
-Can not quit during puzzles
-During puzzles you must manually make the game crash if you want to leave the game; However doing this will make you have to restart the entire chapter, including the puzzle

~Verdict~
~Only buy it if on sale for under a US Dollar
~I would not recommend buying Morphopolis at the full price of Five US Dollars

~That is all~
~Indie Reviewer Soggy Banana~

reviewText:
A nice short (depends on how fast you solve the puzzles) game with relaxing music and wonderfully drawn scenes. I would say it is a relaxing game, but the insects you play walk are very slow paced. This can be really annoying (and thus no longer relaxing) as you will often know where certain objects are hidden but cannot collect them yet because you have to wait for your insect to catch up with your desperate mouse-clicking.

Aside from the last puzzle the puzzles are not easy, but do-able if you think about them for a bit. The last puzzle is quite hard and to be honest I don't think I'd like to try my hand at it again. It was quite frustrating.

All in all a really nice game which I can only recommend if you're looking for something casual.

Its o.k. The art is very nice and the music is also rather soothing. Sadly theres little to no gameplay. Its a hidden object game with some very simple puzzles. Movement is slow and can be annoying with pathing.

This game is made to look and sound pretty but the gameplay seems uninspired and just too simple. The enviroment and interactions could be more animated and lively, something to make it feel less like a picture and more like a living world, to give it some charm.

I would reccomend buying it on sale when it dips below a dollar but I couldnt see myself buying it for the 5$ normal price.

reviewText:
don't let the screenshots, or the trailers fool you. the game may looks easy and relaxing. but actually it's really hard which likely would lead you into frustation and rage quit. LOL. seriously. the good things are:
fortunately I bought it when it was on a big sale, 95%. nice artworks you will say in the first time you see it. the music is fairly good too. the final puzzle quite challenging, short (can't imagine I have to bear such torture longer), perfect game, and last of course I know about insect more. how hard they life actually are. no one to explain, learn all by yourself. random trial and error. and you know, to see such puzzle they have to solve, they are actually pretty smart too. :/  I learn to appreciate them more now.

if you wanna buy it, only on big sale. your welcome.

reviewText:
Morphopolis is a point-and-click adventure game that is both beautiful and unique; However its gameplay is slow,boring, and repetative while being relaxing at the same time. After thirty minutes of gameplay I wanted to stop, I was constantly wondering around playing I-Spy with the game. I would say that around 80% of this game is I-Spy with insanely slow movement. The other 20% is spent doing puzzles which were mostly unique and condusing. Overall I would say to only get this game while it's on sale just to see wheter you like it or not. If at full-price, then there is definitely something better to spend your money on.

~Pros~
+Beautiful Artwork
+Unique Artwork
+Unique Game Concept
+Unique Puzzles
+Casual Players Welcome
+All Achievements Unlocked in only one Playthrough

~Cons~
-No Options
-No Controls
-No Audio
-No Video Options
-Repetative Gameplay
-Repetative Soundtrack
-Two Hours of Gameplay
-Extremely Slow Gameplay
-Buggy Movement
-Zero Turtorial or Instruction
-Confusing Gameplay
-Only Auto-Saves after each chapter
-If you leave during a 45 minute chapter, you must restart
-Can not quit during puzzles
-During puzzles you must manually make the game crash if you want to leave the game; However doing this will make you have to restart the entire chapter, including the puzzle

~Verdict~
~Only buy it if on sale for under a US Dollar
~I would not recommend buying Morphopolis at the full price of Five US Dollars

~That is all~
~Indie Reviewer Soggy Banana~

reviewText:
I received this game as a gift from a good friend.

At its heart, Morphopolis plays like a hidden object game with several simple, yet fun puzzles thrown in.

The artwork is quite charming, bright and colorful. It would be at home in classic illustrated children's book.

If I had one gripe about gameplay is that there is a point and click element to the movement (or more correctly, hold a direction and click) which is quite slow and sometimes it's not obvious what areas of the screen transition to a new area. That said you can at least click on your little bug several times to send out little 'feeler' particles that branch off in the different directions you can move to, although you may have to be much closer than you'd think for this to show you a path you've been missing.

It has a simple hint system, clicking the ? in the upper right hand corner will have the game point out an object you can interact with at the time. It has a cool down timer after use, so it's not really abusable. If you've found all there is to do in an area it will simply beep instead of pointing out something, however it still wont tell you where you should go, which again can be a little annoying if you've missed an area transition.

The game is short and can be beaten in under two hours, I played it in several short bursts over a couple of days. It may take you longer if you're farming trading cards.

Over all, Morphopolis feels like it was aimed at a younger audience. I'd highly recommend it to anyone with child or young adult interested in entomology (the study of insects.) Those who have a marked phobia of insects however, might find the game a little creepy (and crawly).

reviewText:
I was originally drawn in by Morphopolis's vibrant, hand-drawn art. It's color palettes are rich, the environments are complex, and its cast of flora is so lush it almost borders on surreal. It is, without a doubt, one of the most visually stunning hidden object games that I've played  to date.

Unfortunately, those stunning visuals make for unclear level layouts and hidden objects that are almost indecipherable from the scenery. The game's graphic elements encourage rampant clicking and inspire frustration in the player when they suddenly discover there's a whole new area they would have known they could explore if they had just climbed up one particular branch (that is, of course, identical to all the other branches that you can't climb). Many of the levels were aesthetically pleasing, but irritatingly busy.

The biggest flaw in Morphopolis, however, is the movement speed of your character. Your bug crawls at an agonizingly slow pace and is often confused by the clicks of your mouse, causing them to dance" back and forth wildly. On top of that
date: despite being able to spot many hidden objects as you advance through the screens of the level
recommended: you can't collect them until you've received a task from another bug. The game forces you to walk back and forth several more times than necessary to collect items you already knew were there.\n\nIf you can get it for cheap and are a fan of hidden object games I would pick it up just for the art
hoursPlayed: but otherwise there are more polished hidden object games to spend your time and money on in the Steam store that are guaranteed to give you more fun than the slow

If you like your hidden object games with obtuse puzzles, obscure objectives, painfully inept controls, contrived parameters for progression, incessant backtracking between screens along with movement so painfully slow it will take literally 20 seconds to move between said screens then this game is for you.\n\nPersonally I don't enjoy that kind of thing, in fact I found this game such torture I'd recommend its use on prisoners in Guantanamo Bay; I think it would be far more effective than waterboarding.

Morphopolis is a non-traditional hidden object adventure that is more about mood, balance, and aesthetics than your more garden variety story and character driven gaming experience.  Artwork and innovation are its strong points from the beautifully hand drawn look to the unusual tasks you go about setting nature right.  Although slightly frustrating controls and sorely lacking tutorials make the game a little confusing at points, it is still a development achievement in its own right.  I recommend Morphopolist for it for someone who wants to try something unusual and those who are diehard adventure completionists, while those who are easily frustrated or confused should stay clear.

reviewText: Relaxing, great soundtrack, amazing art and good puzzles. The only words there are the credits and the name of the game itself. Basically, you have to comprehend every visual element. So it might take a while for you to understand what you have to do when you open one of the puzzles. Trust me, it will put your mind to the test. You'll soon realize that each stage somewhat tells a story if you look deep into it. And it all sums up to a quite open ending which i'm a little dissatisfied at. Please make a sequel! That would make this game more meaningful.\n\nA game for the patient mind. Don't complain about the bugs walking too slow. It shows how this surreal art is also like peering into reality.

Morphopolis is a beautiful slow paced hidden object puzzle game. The artwork is mesmerising, the music is calming, and although the controls can be a little awkward at times, I love how smooth the transition between panels is- including the ability to grab last second object as you're already moving offscreen.

With regards to the puzzles- the tangled string and beetle swap ones being the best in my opinion, were well thought out and had a challenging yet fun level of difficulty. In retrospect one thing I loved (Though hated at the time) was the complete lack of instruction within the puzzles. On more than one or two I would be sat there wondering what the heck I was even supposed to do (Flower placement puzzle), but it's a great way to get you thinking and working hard for your achievements.

All in all, I got this game for about 15p in the Halloween sale, and I really wish I'd paid more for it. ¬£4 would have been a stretch, but I'd say this one is definitely worth ¬£3. At almost 2 hours long, it's a perfect game for a nice chill evening :)

I just bought Morphopolis today, it was very cheap on sale and the game was an amazing experience.
You play as an insect and you have to salvage other insects that are dead or almost dead, not quite sure about that. To do so you have to solve puzzles. Most of them are easy except the very last one.

Morphopolis is really beautiful, the game appeal lies in the colorful hand-drawn art. It might look complicated at first glance but actually all you need to do is search for hidden objects and think a little to solve puzzles. Definitely worth a try, but I would wait for a discount since you can finish it in an hour or so.

Goodness, what can be said about this game? It's fairly short (finished it in about two hours myself), depending on how quickly you figure out said game's mechanics, and it came go quickly. It's odd watching your character, if you can even call it that since it's a small bug you control, change and 'metamorphosis' into another bug and onward. Clicking and very heavily needed on back and forth searching for the hidden objects around the level, some things are hidden in one area are needed for something that is in an area back in the beginning of the level while others are needed for later on in said level or higher up towards something at the top of the screen, items are needed to persuade certain other bugs to let you pass and it can get frustrating, but it's a calming game once you get around to figuring out how to do so.\n\nIt's a mixed sort of game, if you are into puzzle solving and hidden games, you might like this small short game, if not then stay away since you could get confused and show great regret in buying in, all in all it is just up to the person who wants to buy it, I recomend it to those puzzle lovers and those who like hidden objects.

reviewText: One of the most visually stimulating puzzle games I've ever played. The puzzles vary in difficulty, most can be completed quickly but a few of the more challenging ones can take a while. For me the illustration style of this game combined with the music earns a 10/10 rating. Short but quite satisfying. For 19 cents during the 2015 Steam Summer Sale, I consider it a steal, not sure if I'd pay $4.99 for it though.
simple puzzles, bad bug steering, but just beautiful draw

Morphopolis is a puzzle game mixed with a point and click hidden object genre. It's casual and slow paced, yet redeems itself with the artistic choices and atmosphere it has. The scenery on every screen is packed with details and every environment is unique, same goes for the puzzles - every puzzle is based on it's own theme, and plays completely different from each other.
The only dealbreaking issue is how the game controls and how cheaply it's ported to the PC. First of all, there are no settings for the game whatsoever - no resolution or windowed mode, sound, or control adjustments. Second of all, since the game is intended to run on a tablet, everything is done through on-screen UI, the keyboard is completely useless and the controls are limited to mouse movement and left click, even the pause menu isn't mapped to the ESC key as a common courtesy.  As a result, character movement is nearly broken, the puzzle controls are heavy and deliberate, as one would use the tablet.
Additionally the game does deal with a lot of death, including, but not limited, to collecting, reanimating and essentially playing a puzzle game with a multitude of corpses. Collecting dismembered or torn limbs from fallen insects is also a reoccuring theme, which isn't necessarily an issue, but can be seen as more brutal than expected.
The game lasted me only 3 hours, but it's worth for the experience.
For its price its not a bad game a little short but you cant expect much for what i paid, its a challenge and also very visually pleasing.
I would recommend this game for its value of $0.21 cents. You get your money's worth mainly from the last puzzle: Prepare to cry.
THE BEST GAME IN THE WORLD, PUZZELS AS MASSIVE ONLINE BATTLES, LOTS OF ROLE PLAYING AND FRIENDLY TO CASUAL GAMERS AND PROS

reviewText:
Morphopolis is a sadistic puzzle game, in which you control the movements of a specimen from the next level of insect evolution. This insect tracks down notably larger dying insects, then patches them up and feeds them, pretends to be their friend. But as soon as the larger insect is healed and ready to move again, the one you control penetrates it's head, burrows it's way inside the poor insects' brain cavity and takes control over their body. Afterwards, you begin to track down the next pray whom to repeat the process on.

The game ends in you going inside a tunnel. It is understandable that the developers cut out the following part in which you take over a human, go lay your eggs in the newborn wing of a hospital and watch your children taking control of the newborn humans, and eventually, your race turning every other specie on the planet to mindless controllable puppets.

Not recommended for underage audiences.

Stunning Graphic/Artworks , and the BGM is marvellous .Definitely worth every penny , plus I bought it on Summer Sale (96% yo) ...definetely makes my day :D

Morphopolis is a game about bugs, some of the smallest creatures in the world and they are rather fascinating and very important to our environment aswell.

This game is a point and click game with puzzles to solve and hidden objects to discover and find, this will help the small bug on its journey of life. This is a very pretty and colourful game, and not very difficult to play.

Also you must complete each chapter, if you decide to stop halfway through you will have to start from the beginning of that chapter, as there is no exit feature while in a level so I just completed them and exited the game afterwards.

Morphopolis is a very short game and the achievements are easy to earn. I found the last puzzle rather challenging, but I won't doubt that anyone can't managed to solve it and get 100% of theachievements :)

Great little indie game! Beautiful artwork some neet little puzzles only negative is moving your little bug friend around can be a bit awkward and some of the puzzles might entail some random clicking untill you figure out what you're ment to do, but at 96% off it's well worth the pickup, mint!

(7.5/10)

Cute little 'adventure' type game, with a very distinctive art style.  Probably most targeted for those with kids as the cute colors and all the various bugs will definitely be something compatible with kids (though you might want to hang around to help them with the puzzles).

The difficulty of the non puzzle bits is a bit easier, making for a relatively relaxed play through.  The only possible frustration is how slow some of your bugs will move, it can drag some levels on when you know you have to collect a certain number of things and you know where they are, but it takes ages for yer bug to crawl from screen to screen.

Overall though I did have fun and would come back for more of the art and chill music.

It is a series of beautiful animated paintings featuring the quiet alien world of an insect, full of organic shapes and vibrant colors. The interaction is minimal (look for objects and solve simple puzzles), but it forces you to pay attention, appreciate the art, and possibly tune yourself on the strange mood and slow pace of the surroundings.

PROS
+ Artwork
+ Music
+ Basically Free if you buy it as part of the currently offered Art Appreciation Pack Bundle and sell the dropped cards.
+1 Perfect game in about 1.5 hours (The rest of my playtime consists of the game idling in the background, waiting for the card drops.)
+ Relaxing if you manage to not let the terrible controls annoy you.


CONS
- Terrible Controls: Can you call it controls" if it's just one button? LMB is used to both direct your bug (hold) and activate stuff (click). Well
date: your bug constantly gets stuck somewhere
recommended: spinning around until you find the perfect angle to unstick him. Also
hoursPlayed: it sometimes just turns around and walks out of the zone you're in when you click on something. If it weren't for these issues and the incredibly slow walking speed of the bugs
voteText: the game could probably be completed in half an hour.\n- The Puzzle Difficulty seems to be aimed at children
helpfulPercent: while the complete lack of direction or explanations certainly is not. There's also bugs crawling inside the husks of dead
votesHelpful:
bigger bugs to somehow take control of their body. So I have no idea what to think.


CONCLUSION
If there were a "meh" option
votesTotal: this would be the game to use it for. If you're really into it after looking at the gameplay trailer
commentsCount: if possible). What you see is what you get
column16: i.e. slowly crawling through slightly animated drawings and solving undemanding puzzles in between.\n\nIt definitely has its uses for playing the Steam Meta Game
column17: so I'm recommending it for that reason alone.\n"

I just bought Morphopolis today, it was very cheap on sale and the game was an amazing experience.
You play as an insect and you have to salvage other insects that are dead or almost dead, not quite sure about that. To do so you have to solve puzzles. Most of them are easy except the very last one.
Beautiful graphics, nice music and the fact that the game does not guide you is a plus in this case. This games makes it fun to find out what you have to do. But you need a little patience. Morphopolis is not for restless players. And it's short, you can finish the game in about 2.5 hours.

A short hidden object, art gallery, puzzle game. Really beautiful backgrounds.
All of the puzzles are a different type so there's variety.
The bug moves slow so patience is needed. There's no explanation so you have to think it out.
It was a fun experience. I liked it.

nice and relaxing

Nice game, although very short. Completed within 2 hours, although if people get stuck on a puzzle - quite possible on the last one - it may take a bit longer.

Saying that, the game is very cheap (I even had a coupon to make it cheaper). So despite the length of the game I definitely feel like I got my money's worth.

There is a bit of backtracking between screens which is disappointing but as it was so cheap I can't complain.

If the price ever goes up I wouldn't, but as things stand I recommend this game.

I enjoyed Morphopolis. It's a casual game, where you solve puzzles and find hidden items within the vibrant magnified insect world.

Pros
+Beautiful Artwork
+Unique Artwork
+Unique Game Concept
+Unique Puzzles
+Casual Players Welcome
+All Achievements Unlocked in only one Playthrough

Cons
-Repetative Gameplay
-Repetative Soundtrack
-Two Hours of Gameplay
-Extremely Slow Gameplay
-Buggy Movement
-Zero Turtorial or Instruction
-Only Auto-Saves after each chapter

reviewText:
Morphopolis is a relaxing point and click game. You play as different bugs collecting items and accomplishing simple tasks across a few beautiful levels. The entire game is spent looking for hidden objects and completing miscellaneous puzzles to gather more items. While it is gorgeous and sort of fun, it's not very memorable and it is extremely slow and short.

Pros‚óò The art is beautiful and detailed, but it doesn't make it too difficult to find hidden objects.
‚óò Most of the puzzles are challenging at first but they're simple once you get the hang of them. They're not repetitive.
‚óò The achievements are all obtainable over the course of the game, there are no secrets.
‚óò The game does offer hints if you get stuck.
‚óò Cards!
Cons‚óò Very short, only five small levels and maybe a little more than an hour of gameplay.
‚óò No mid-level saving.
‚óò The entire game mostly consists of walking back and forth extremely slowly to get new stuff in the same areas you've already seen.
‚óò Hints can be vague and not very helpful.

Had my character actually moved at a decent pace, the game probably would've lasted 30-45 minutes. You could easily go get a much larger and more interesting game for the price of $5. If the game is on sale, I definitely recommend trying it out, though.

reviewText: A fun, little, simplistic puzzle game that relies heavily on art and point-and-click style gameplay. As you metamorphosize through various insects collecting camoflauged objects on the screen. The puzzles are nothing too hard mainly things like memory match or putting together a insect mosaic, however the game gives you little to no instructions on what the object is or what you are supposed to do. reviewText: This game is beautiful. The art is beautiful, the sound is beautiful. It's a beautiful game. It was clearly made by artists, and talented ones at that.\n\nSadly, aritsts do not always make the best game designers. The controls are awkward and confusing, movement is painfully slow and difficult to control, and there are times when a little guidance would be helpful - but none is offered. I'm thinking in particular of one puzzle where the pieces can only be moved as they are in those peg solitaire games - but there is absolutely no indication given of this. There's a whole forum thread full of people wondering why they can't do anything in this puzzle, assuming it's a bug. Difficulty is good, but obtuseness is... less good. Given how many alpha testers" they list on their credits
date: I'd have expected them to realize and repair some of these large flaws\n\nStill

reviewText:
Lukewarm recommendation, at the price I got it for (25 cents), and even then I'm not sure it's worth the time. At full price it's a waste of money, but at least it has cards and achievements.

It's mostly a simple hidden object game and fetch quest, with a few low-rent common puzzles (pipe, jigsaw, slider, etc) that have been seen a million times to draw out the game time. For the most part, the hidden objects are blatant, but I had trouble with some green ones given that there's just so much green everywhere. I didn't see anything original anywhere.

It's somewhat pretty, in a 1998 Newgrounds original sort of way, but it certainly isn't awe-inspiring art. Its Flash roots are very obvious. The music is good, in an unmemorable way. The controls are abominably bad, though, requiring you to hold down the mouse button to keep moving and regularly move your mouse around because the pathing is so bad and your bug gets confused. You move at a snail's pace, too. Too bad you don't get to play as one....

A much better game in the same vein is Violett. Do yourself a favor and play that instead.

reviewText:
7.2/10 - Beautifully Artful; Short and Stellar

This game is usually really cheap so I recommend it. The art style is one of a kind. You are tasked with finding items and making things happen. Most things believe it or not have to do with metamorphism; collect pollen... watch flower grow... collect the end product.

There are also puzzles thrown in make you think, but are in no way too difficult to enjoy. Only 5-6 stages on this game so it's pretty short. I'd grab this on sale or in a bundle if possible.

Worth $3ish

reviewText: Let me start by saying that this is definitely the prettiest Hidden Object game that I have ever played. The graphics are just beautiful to look at and the music is very pleasant. However, I must point out that the interface can be very clunky at times. There are no directions in the game, and no text at all. This can lead to frustration when you don't realize that you could have been double clicking on your character to interact with something, or when you are staring at a puzzle with little or no idea of what you are meant to do... so I don't really recommend this game to anyone that doesn't have the patience to experiment and figure things out on their own. For what I paid, I really did get my money's worth and more.

reviewText:
This game only took two hours for me to complete, which made me pay roughly ‚Ç¨0.09 per hour, which I got back by gaining three cards which can be sold for roughly ‚Ç¨0.2~, buit I would have spent ‚Ç¨5 for this game, and here‚Äôs why.

First off, there‚Äôs no real option menu, which annoyed me at first since there‚Äôs no way to change the volume nor a real interface. Clearly this is more suited for an iPad where you can sit and relax with just your index finger but I‚Äôm so happy that I played it on 1920x1080p since the graphics are amazing. The artstyle is colorful and it helps when it comes to how the puzzles are built, forcing you to admire the artstyle while playing. This game is slowing down the pace, forcing you to actually study the environment in search for clues or hidden key all while listening to a wonderful soundtrack that‚Äôs soothing and mysterious at the same time.

There‚Äôs a downside though, the controls can be clunky and the insect you‚Äôre playing is moving so slow which makes it mildly infuriating when it comes to running back and forward when it comes to solving puzzles. Yet, this was an amazing gaming experience, and this is coming from someone who usually ignores the puzzles and ragequit while pretending to be intellectually superior since I haven‚Äôt let the game prove me wrong.

HIGHLY recommend.

reviewText:
Pros:
Beautiful art
Animation really improves this game - you aren't just staring at a static image
Quite a relaxing game
Cards/badge
Music
Hint feature that is charged by movement
High quality multi-stage levels (new areas unlocked within the level as you progress through it)

Cons:
Price quite high for a short game with little replay value (imo), however I bought it in the sales when it was without doubt amazing value for the 2 hours gameplay I got out of it.
Ran out of gameplay before I got all the card drops (got 2 hours gameplay and 1 card drop), so having to leave it open to get the remaining 2 drops
Doesn't save progress within levels - if you leave the level before finishing it you lose all progress in that level, levels aren't too long so this isn't gamebreaking, but it can be a pain
Sometimes it's hard to tell where you can go/what to do, but there is a hint feature that is charged by moving, which negates this
Character movement is quite slow (although this is thematic) and can be a bit odd - hard to tell where you can go/direct your movement
Only 5 levels

Overall I would strongly recommend this game, however personally I would only buy it when it is on sale or if more content was introduced. (I bought it for ¬£0.20 which was incredibly value.)

First off, there‚Äôs no real option menu, which annoyed me at first since there‚Äôs no way to change the volume nor a real interface. Clearly this is more suited for an iPad where you can sit and relax with just your index finger but I‚Äôm so happy that I played it on 1920x1080p since the graphics are amazing. The artstyle is colorful and it helps when it comes to how the puzzles are built, forcing you to admire the artstyle while playing. This game is slowing down the pace, forcing you to actually study the environment in search for clues or hidden key all while listening to a wonderful soundtrack that‚Äôs soothing and mysterious at the same time.

There‚Äôs a downside though, the controls can be clunky and the insect you‚Äôre playing is moving so slow which makes it mildly infuriating when it comes to running back and forward when it comes to solving puzzles. Yet, this was an amazing gaming experience, and this is coming from someone who usually ignores the puzzles and ragequit while pretending to be intellectually superior since I haven‚Äôt let the game prove me wrong.

HIGHLY recommend.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pros:
Beautiful art
Animation really improves this game - you aren't just staring at a static image
Quite a relaxing game
Cards/badge
Music
Hint feature that is charged by movement
High quality multi-stage levels (new areas unlocked within the level as you progress through it)

Cons:
Price quite high for a short game with little replay value (imo), however I bought it in the sales when it was without doubt amazing value for the 2 hours gameplay I got out of it.
Ran out of gameplay before I got all the card drops (got 2 hours gameplay and 1 card drop), so having to leave it open to get the remaining 2 drops
Doesn't save progress within levels - if you leave the level before finishing it you lose all progress in that level, levels aren't too long so this isn't gamebreaking, but it can be a pain
Sometimes it's hard to tell where you can go/what to do, but there is a hint feature that is charged by moving, which negates this
Character movement is quite slow (although this is thematic) and can be a bit odd - hard to tell where you can go/direct your movement
Only 5 levels

Overall I would strongly recommend this game, however personally I would only buy it when it is on sale or if more content was introduced. (I bought it for ¬£0.20 which was incredibly value.)
