reviewText:
I thoroughly enjoyed the experience of playing Morphopolis. The concept was pretty straight-forward and the puzzles were stimulating enough without being too over-demanding. I actually found it easy to unwind whilst playing this - the colours and sounds created a soothing effect.
Morphopolis was compared somewhere to The Room (another game I loved immensely). My experience of the two games differed in that I completed Morphopolis in one sitting, whilst with The Room I reached several points where I became stuck and had to take a break before resuming.
When I played Morphopolis there were  five levels and they didn't take too long to get through. It would be nice if more levels were added or a follow-up released.
This is a great game and I highly recommend it to anyone.

reviewText:
'Morphopolis' is a calm symphonic, seeming surrealistic, game about the (micro/macro) world of insects with puzzle elements.

Desc:
You start as a caterpillar and you're developing at the end of each level (5 at total) to the next higher stage. Within each level you have to solve several puzzles like sorting colored seed from a flower at the right position. First of all you have to click the objects which have your point of interest and then the game will show you what kind of objects you have to collect. Collect the hidden objects and click the (POI) object again to solve the gathering. You control your figure only with your mouse by pressing the left mouse button to the position where you want to go. Be aware: At some routes are crossroads you may not see at the first time.

Pros:
+ awesome looking graphics
+ great atmosphere
+ good calm soundtrack
+ slow game experience
+ puzzle elements are overwhelmingly brisk (which not seem to be false)
+ figure has at each stage of development one ability (suck water drops, wing beat to open seeds, ..)

Cons:
- non-intuitive controlling (IMHO)
- short game duration (could have much more levels)
- no other game modes or chapters (where you would for instance develop to other insects like a butterfly instead of a bee)

Recommended, even if it's not on sale, because it's a very interesting and brisk game, where you will not find one genre that fits 100% to. The world needs more fresh game concepts like this!

7/10

reviewText:
This is the most beautifully illustrated game I have ever seen. It is a very unique point-and-click game. The concept of being an insect and going on a journey of metomorphosis is quite original. The hidden objects and puzzles were not too difficult, but they weren't too easy, either.

The point-and-click mechanics could use some work. It pretty much required clicking very carefully directly in front of the bug in the direction you want it to go. It could not find its own path when there were multiple ways to go. It would also turn around and go to a previous screen if the clicking was not precise enough.

There is one thing that takes a lot of fun out of this game: the final beetle slider puzzle. It's so difficult that there's a long discussion thread about it. Slider puzzles are games unto themselves. To put one into such a pleasant, casual game is just infuriating. Luckily, someone made a solver to end the insanity.

Still, it's a pleasant game to experience and admire.

---

reviewText: I recommend this game only for people looking to get an easy 100% achievement game and some trading cards.  I got it for $0.24, and at that price it was worth it to me for the achievements and the cards.\n\nThis is a fairly easy puzzle game.  There was only one puzzle (the last one) that I considered difficult.  I found the controls for moving my insect (point and click with mouse) to be annoying.  Most of the time you are looking for hidden objects on the screen.  After finding the required objects on each level, there is then a puzzle or two to move on.  There are five levels.  It's very casual, there are no real risks or ways to mess anything up.  You just keep trying until you find the objects or solve the puzzle.  Maybe about 2 hours of total gameplay for 100% achievements, possibly longer if you get stuck on some of the puzzles.

reviewText:
First off, let me preface this by saying that I don't normally take the time to write a review unless I feel strongly about a game, and this one definitely has that covered. I just can't sit here and let anyone else fall into the ratings trap that this game is.

This game is fun for about the first five minutes. From then on it becomes infuriatingly slow, tedious, and downright annoying. On top of that it has pretty much no playability, it took me just over an hour (it felt like five) to complete this game and get all of the achievements. Even after i have beaten the game and have literally nothing else to do on it, it didn't even drop me one of the trading cards.

In short, there are plenty of things you could spend your money on instead of this game, like a soda, or a candy bar, or just throwing your money into the garbage. I would never recommend this game to anyone and now that I am through with it, I will never touch this game again, not even to try for the card drops.

reviewText:
A brief puzzle game for the patient.

If you've played and enjoyed Tiny Bang Story, you will most likely enjoy Morphopolis. While controlling an insect, you retrieve a certain number of certain objects for certain taskgivers whether they be other insects or plants. The game in all takes maybe around 30-40 minutes. This 30-40 minutes can easily be filled with relaxation for this breed of game has its calming effects with its soothing music and simple find-the-things gameplay. However, if you are not the most patient person, you may not enjoy this game due to the slow movement speed of the insect that you control to move through different parts of a level. When you know what you are to do, you complete the task in a matter of seconds. It takes just as long, if not longer, to move between the different sections to progress.

Overall, if you are patient and want a low-stress game to occupy yourself for under an hour, I would reccomend Tiny Bang Story, but this would come soon after.

reviewText:
This game is amazing.

It's not the kind you usually see on Steam. It's usually either hat simulators or rock simulators, so seeing something so artistic was new. The art in this game is beautiful, and so is the music. I would honestly pay for an OST also.

The game has a cute, melancholy feel to it, and the art and music are very fitting with each other. It's essentially a hidden object game, but there's also some puzzles and point and click. The gameplay is hard enough to keep it a challenge, but easy enough to make it casual and fun.

The one downfall this game has is the shortness of it. I've beaten the game in my playtime, which is 2.5 hours. (Well, almost. I kind of ragequit on that last puzzle, but I'll beat it later lol.) I'm not sure if the price is worth it. The art, music, and gameplay is tremendous, but the shortness is kind of upsetting. Hopefully there's a sequel or update in the future.

So overall, yes. I do recommend this game, even for the original price. But, if it is on sale, buy it, because it's a steal. (I got it for 24 cents.)

reviewText: I'll admit it, I only bought the game simply because it was on sale for really cheap. However I found this game to be overwhelmingly charming with both its beautiful presentation and simple yet relaxing game play. The art work for the game is beautiful as well as all the ambient sounds and background music. Despite all its beauty and creativity, the game is very short and can be completed in only a couple of hours. This being said it is very much a worthwhile game to play! It gave me a nice break from the chaos of my normal library of games, providing me with a peaceful and enchanting experience. If it's on sale I'd completely recommend checking Morphopolis out.\n

reviewText:
A brief puzzle game for the patient.

If you've played and enjoyed Tiny Bang Story, you will most likely enjoy Morphopolis. While controlling an insect, you retrieve a certain number of certain objects for certain taskgivers whether they be other insects or plants. The game in all takes maybe around 30-40 minutes. This 30-40 minutes can easily be filled with relaxation for this breed of game has its calming effects with its soothing music and simple find-the-things gameplay. However, if you are not the most patient person, you may not enjoy this game due to the slow movement speed of the insect that you control to move through different parts of a level. When you know what you are to do, you complete the task in a matter of seconds. It takes just as long, if not longer, to move between the different sections to progress.

Overall, if you are patient and want a low-stress game to occupy yourself for under an hour, I would reccomend Tiny Bang Story, but this would come soon after.

reviewText:
If you want to run this on a PC with a mouse, good luck.

There are no instructions.
There are no settings. You cannot control resolution, windowed mode, and so on.
There are no controls, effectively. You're supposed to click and hold to make the caterpillar move. It'll do that a little, but you'll get stuck at some point and wherever it is that you're supposed to click and hold to make it move again is completely, utterly, counter-intuitive.

I'm uninstalling before full-on nerdrage kicks in.

reviewText:
Well, that game was strange.

Graphics: Probably the best thing about this game. It's very pretty to look at, the colors are quite vibrant and interesting. The problem is that everything is so colorful that it's hard to tell what's part of the background and what you can walk/click on, which unfortunately is the main game mechanic.

Story: Uhh...basically you're a bug trying to bring all the other bugs back to life or save their buddies. Yeah it's a little weird.

Gameplay: REALLY BORING AND SLOW...I guess you could use this game to relax before you go to sleep? It certainly made me tired. You play as a bug that moves ridiculously slowly across branches that are terribly hard to distinguish from the rest of the background. This is basically a point and click game in which you click on various objects that you see labeled on the left side of your screen until you've gotten all of them. Each level has one or two puzzles that are usually knockoffs of pretty popular puzzles (matching games, checkers, and finally a rubix cube type puzzle which I couldn't complete in 30 minutes so I gave up). That final puzzle is absolutely ridiculous, so unfortunately I couldn't beat the game because I got sick of pressing buttons to no avail.

Other than that, the music is kinda nice. It's very ambient, and gets annoying after you've heard it for a while, which is usually what happens given how slow the bug moves. I got this game for 20 cents and I'd say it's worth about that. I could see this being a free online flash game. There are only 5 levels, I (almost) beat it in a little over an hour. Get it if you like lots of bugs and looking at pretty pictures and moving really slowly. 3/10

reviewText:
Morphopolis is beautiful, occasionally frustrating, and short.

What I liked:
Gorgeous artwork
More gorgeous artwork (it deserves to be mentioned twice)
Fairly original concept
Enjoyable mini puzzles
What distracted from my enjoyment:
Bug movement issues: I would occasionally get my bug stuck on something and be unable to move it.  Alternatively, sometimes it would interpret an attempt to click on anything, anywhere on the screen as a command to move to the screen above if I were near the top edge.  Also by the end of the game, I found I was impatient with the speed my bug moved.  Apparently it had crossbred with a snail somewhere in there.
At least one minipuzzle needs to be a little more dynamic so players can figure out how it works faster.  It took me about ten minutes to figure out that I was supposed to click and drag pebbles, partially because when I tried clicking and dragging there was no feedback or indication that it was working.  (10 minutes to figure out to click and drag.  Maybe 2 minutes to solve.  Meh.)
It's short.  Really short.  Five chapters short.  I'm a very slow, stare-at-and-enjoy-the-scenery kind of gamer and I finished it in 3.5 hours.  (Confession time: the final puzzle took me 1.5 hours.  I'm terrible at those.)  There's also very little replay value except to look at the art.
Recommended?
On sale? Yes. Definitely.
Regularly priced?  This depends on how highly you value creativity, puzzles, art, replay value, etc.  Personally, the art helps, but I need a longer game to justify full price.

reviewText:
Other reviews of this game have stated that Morphopolis is better as a work of art than a game, but I have to disagree because having bought primarily for the aesthetic of it I found out very quickly that this fails as both a game and as an art project.

First, throughout the game there are huge lags in frame rate, which I initially thought was just part of the trippy look of the whole thing, then I thought it was a problem with my computer. But nope, I can run Skyrim with no drop in frame rate on my laptop but this simplistic thing jarrs just by having your insect change direction or if there are too much stuff going on in a particular level.

The art work that made me buy the game in the first place quickly became irritating the more I played, the style is not well integrated into the gameplay at all, the title screen made the animation look fluid but when playing the game you often just have your legs animated while they drag your whole immovable body through the levels, the same type of animation cheats they use on most of the non-playable insects and environments, making the whole experience look clumpy and ugly.

The controls are equally awkward, you don't use wasd keys because I guess that would not be ‚Äúarty‚Äù enough for the developers, you have to hold the left mouse button in the direction you want to go and there's a 50% chance you might actually get there if you don't have to find something to click on to solve a tiresome puzzle. Most of my playthrough was spent just trying to get my bug in the right direction so that I could crawl on a narrow route through invisible walls just to collect foliage to open the next level. Only to find I had to backtrack to collect a different set of items to actually move on, if they had individual puzzles open every time I had to do this that might have been barely tolerable, many times it's just busy work to pad the game.

I spent on average more than 20 minutes doing this alone nearly every level, this is already a short game and most of playing it is navigating nonsensical pre-determined pathways that made me want to kick my laptop into the ocean, if it wasn't through my stubbornness and the promise of achievements and trading cards I would have given up much earlier.

The hidden object portion of Morphopolis is really difficult, and not in a challenging or clever way, just in a frustrating eye-squinting way. This is where the art work really works against game, the objects you need often blend too well into the background or are so small you really have to get close to the screen to truly see them, or you have to access them by clicking the bug you control at a specific time, I only found this out through randomly clicking everything in sight and looking at let's plays, the game does not give you any of this information.
Most of the levels are a homogeneous mass of art, which would be fine if it was just a very detailed background for a different kind of game, as something you have to slog through in order to complete the game it's a sickening and confusing mess that I tired of very quickly.

Which brings me to the puzzles, you don't get much help in this game, that's not necessarily a bad thing, but it is if finding the hidden objects you need often comes down to clicking everywhere and hoping you get what you need, looking through a walkthrough (where many of the let's players seemed just as lost as I was), or hitting the hint button which straight up tells you where objects are but only when it's charged up and when you're in the right area. Can't find how to access the area you need to be in through the invisible walls? Hint button not fully charged until the next minute? Well tough, you have to wait for the hint button to charge and if no hints are available just wonder about hoping that you can reach where you need to be by clicking on anything, maybe the game will help you find how to complete the level, maybe it won't, maybe you'll figure it out through trial and error, you probably won't, there is no merciful god here.

And while we're on the subject, ‚Äúimmersion‚Äù does not mean slow and ponderous, being ‚Äúarty‚Äù doesn't mean just plodding through weird surroundings with a weird non-story, you can't layer your game with arty visuals and call it immersive without any further effort on story, character or playability. While I'm sure many defenders of this game found it beautiful and meaningful, I and many others were praying for a skip button or any kind of save feature where we didn't have to go at a snails pace through the same level over and over again because we had the audacity to want to do stuff we enjoyed or look up a guide. Even an option to get out of some of puzzle modes so you can come back to it later or save so you don't have to repeat everything up until that point would have been a logical thing for this game to have, but I guess functionality doesn't win you illustrator awards so that isn't a feature. If the game wasn't so short it would be completely unplayable because of this, as it is it just makes the game annoying.

This game even fails to do a jigsaw puzzle properly, the art style while pretty (depending on taste) made what should have been a straightforward jigsaw puzzle into a frustrating rage game. Some of the pieces simply did not look like they were supposed to fit, lumps and bumps that were on pieces slotted perfectly into smoother areas, if it wasn't through a process of elimination I doubt I could have solved the puzzle. If this was unintentional then the developers cannot even develop the simplest puzzle with their art style properly, if it was intentional all it did was baffle me and frustrate me further, either way it made what should have been a beautiful game into an ugly experience. This isn't ‚Äúchallenging‚Äù, some of the puzzles fundamentally don't follow reasonable rules, there is no skill involved in these, only guesswork and irritation.

I simply did not care what was going on by level 4, there was no incentive to fully complete level 5 for me, Morphopolis gave me no investment in the gameplay, the story (what little it has) and what few characters we see (if you can call them that since we know nothing about these insects and we can't know anything about them because ‚Äúart‚Äù). I wasn't relaxed or charmed, I was bored and angry, even if the game's conclusion was so mind-blowing that it completely made all the flaws I found in it meaningful I simply cannot muster any energy to give a damn about it at this point.

As a further insult, the achievements feel hollow because they are awarded for just the level and puzzle completions, no easter eggs or prizes for additional effort seem to be on offer, and the trading card drops for me were only available towards the end of the game and are worth squat on the market.

This isn't what a puzzle game should be, this isn't what a hidden object game should be, and it is not what an art game should be. It failed to be good at any of these things, and even though I spent less than 50p on it at the time I still feel ripped off, the developers should feel incredibly lucky to have gotten a positive rating for this.

reviewText:
‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• THIS GAME.  Nice artwork is its ONLY redeeming quality.

All the worst aspects of hidden object games in a fancy-looking package.
-Unclear where you're able to move? Check.
-Rage-inducingly difficult to control? Check.
-No configuration? Check.
-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• story? I'd say the life cycle of some gross bugs is pretty ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, Check.
-Hard/impossible to spot items because they're BENEATH other things? Check.
-Can't save your progress within a stage? Check.
-SLOW gameplay? Check. That ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• crawls slower than molasses.

What a piece of garbage, why are all you idiots recommending it? Being artistic doesn't make it a good game.

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Beautiful Art
+ Good Soundtrack
+ Low Price (in a sale)
+ Challenging puzzles

Cons:
- Awkward controls (on a computer)
- The Bug you control moves veeeeery slowly
- No settings
- No tutorial/guide (not a big problem for myself)
- Black bars at top and bottom (wth?)
- Very short (108 minutes for me)
- No in-between saving (you have to complete the chapter first)

Conclusion: Good game for mobile devices, but sucks on a PC.

reviewText: I should have known a game that looks like an ugly handbag couldn't play well. The controlls are awful, with your insect turning around and going back if you overshoot slightly, or, as it was for me, every single time I tried to move somewhere, at least twice. It's very hard to know where you can go, what to do next, what you're supposed to be hunting, if the irational rage you suddenly feel towards women and insects says more about the game or you... It's a lot of uncertainty to handle, too much for the hints system to address. I got stuck in the second level when the full gamut of places I knew how to access contained no hints, and had to rage-quit. the absence of mid-level saves has a silver lining, in at least excusing my refusal to return to the game.\n\nBasically it was awful and I'm proud of myself to managing to review it without swearing. I did get it for 19p in the sale, so you would think I would be able to contain my anger.

reviewText:
Bought the game for the art style, and on that it delivers. In all other aspects though, it really doesn't.

You control a bug that goes from larvae to some form of avian insect reminiscent of a bumblebee. To do this you crawl (very slowly) from screen to screen through out five short chapters, collecting objects to manipulate the world in different ways. This part is pretty much a hidden objects-game. Sometimes when you have collected all the parts for one of the objectives you are rewarded with a small puzzle. These puzzles aren't anything special. The difficulty of the puzzles are for the most part trivial, but I got stuck twice because of a couple of very misleading or unintuitive elements. And that is all there is to it.

I paid 0,19‚Ç¨ for it, and for that price I think it's worth a play through just for the art. For the regular asking price though, I would not recommend it, for that price I'd expect more game for my money.

Very pretty but it doesn't work right. I think they should check to see if the game is going to work on a desktop with Vista before they put a game up for sale. Designers might also consider putting in an auto solve button where a player can just watch the computer put the petals of the flower in place. As it is I tried the first flower puzzle and wasn't sure the game was working right. Moving the caterpillar along the branch didn't work right. I couldn't get the petals to go where I needed them so I assume there's something wrong with the flower puzzle. I have a bunch of other games with horrible, awkward controls so why would a designer think I wanted to spend a lot of time fiddling and researching how to do the simplest thing with a 25 cent game? Just put in an auto solve button and let me use that. If I want to do it myself I promise I won't use the auto solve. Either that or make sure your game works right and has some adequate text to explain how to get things done.

This game is a wonderful blend of gorgeous art/music and excellent puzzle gameplay. It's challenging in a good way. The levels get a bit repetative, but I still found it fun. The only annoying part is that the bug character you play as moves really slowly. If it could speed up a bit then this game would be perfect. I also wish there were more levels to play, as this ends rather quickly.

-if you like point & click then you will like this game
-if you don't like point & click then you will still like this game because it employs the style in a way that still is fun and challenging.
Very pretty. I found the last challenge a little too hard but after a lot of raging I finally figured it out. Great art work and puzzles, the movement could be improved.

A very nice little game with incredible graphics and beautiful music. Simple logical puzzles and searching for hidden objects in the insect microcosm. However, it's a pity the game teaches nearly nothing about entomology. Too bad that such an opportuinity was wasted.

Gorgeous art and music, interesting gameplay, somewhat similar to Botanicula. But it's a little fatiguing with a mouse - would likely feel better on a touchscreen display (not surprising, considering that it's a port from tablets).
The gameplay is lacking and it is short, but it is relaxing and the art is really nice.  I wouldn't pay full price for it.

Artsy hidden object points&click game. The puzzles are decent and the objects are hard enough to find. There is a hint button with a fairly low cooldown that points to a missed object if there is one in the area of use, or plays a sound meaning there is no hidden object here. There is no introduction or hints to the puzzles; you'll have to figure it all out yourself.

Very clunky movement/pathing. Have to hold down the mouse button to move. A lot of backtracking and the bug is really slow.

The art and music are fantastically atmospheric though. Play for a meditation type entertainment rather than mentally challenging, though some of the puzzles do take some brain work.

All achievements are earned on first run. The ingame menu consists of 'to title menu' and 'return to game' and the title menu of chapter select and exit game. So options are extremely limited. There is no save button, and the puzzles have no exit button, so you'll have to restart level if you have to quit.

The game is short; only five small levels with 2-6 areas in each.

Recommended for the artsy, atmospheric, meditational feeling it has. All the small nuisances makes it not worth its price unless on sale though.

Amazingly Detailed game, really nice Soundtrack to match, and interesting puzzles.The Game is short,  with only 5 levels and has a slow gameplay, but you will definitely enjoy it. Would have been great with moddability  and Steam workshop support. But still a great and very much fun to play.
Fun, short and relaxing puzzle experience. Only had to check walkthrough's 2 times.

Beautiful artwork and music and the puzzles are at a good level of difficulty, though not for the easily frustrated. The gameplay's nothing special but the atmosphere is amazing. Probably not worth $5 but definitely worth picking up on sale.

I'd recommend this for the visual artsy-inclined and those looking for a short, relaxing puzzle experience.

Morphopholis is a beautifully drawn, slow paced hidden object/puzzle game. The artwork is gorgeous and vibrant - as you can see from the screenshots. There are a few puzzles scattered throughout, each of which are completely different. They aren't too hard, they make sense and some require thinking (if you're not just brute forcing it!). The game is short, but it remains fresh throughout, which is nicer than long and filled with boring repetition.

The movement of your bug is sometimes a bit irritating (especially when you're unsure where to click to move to the next zone), but it works - and you can click your bug to see where it can go, traced with what I assume are visualised ant pheromones...! Also some of the puzzles could do with more intuitive controls (the checkers" style puzzle especially - you need to click and drag!).

All together a pleasant
date: laid back experience marred slightly by several jammy controls."

reviewText:
After finishing the game, I was rather neutral on the whole experience. Several aspects were done very well, but unfortunately just as many aspects were poorly executed.

Pros
Great art, always a wonder to look at.
High variety in puzzles.
Unique and clever game design.
Cheap, and even on sale often!
Perfect for your biology gooroo/lover.
Puzzle lovers will have a blast with this game.
Sticks to its format and its formulated basics down to a perfection.

Cons
No explanation on how controls work outside a brief cursor swipe or two.
Music is, albeit well made, annoying and repetitive after hearing the same instruments used repeadetly.
Certain puzzles can become infurriating difficult while others are extremely simple, losing any feel of progressive difficulty.
Some sound effects are loud and annoying, especially the fluttering bugs at the last level
This may be done on purpose, though it is still a con The game turned black once I beat the last level and got the achievment, making the ending anti-climatic (I'm not sure if this was a glitch or not...?)
Movement is really slow and tedious, and moving from environment-to-environment is forced, so one mistake and you'll be stuck watching your bug move to an undesired location.

Neutral/extras
The game was short (1.2 hours at the most for me). Means you won't take much time to finish this (this may be a pro or con depending on the person)
Scientific names for each level achievement! Cool!
No story involved here, just a play and watch game.
Has card drops for trading cards! (More games need these...)
A little difficult to reccomend to many people with the varies of biological and puzzle elements mixed together.

Verdict
Since the game is hard to recommend and has some bugs and issues here and there, but gets the basics down very well, I'd say this is a mixed rating. If puzzle games and wildlife peak your interest, then go for it, else you won't be missing much if you skip this game.

Rating: 6/10, slightly above average.

7/10

It is a very good, soothing experience to chill after playing competitive games.
Well drawn graphics, fitting music and easy to 100% if you want achievements.
Had fun, would definitely recommend.

While this game is very short (I completed it in under two hours without any guides or walkthroughs), it has a gorgeous sense of style and the puzzles are fun and intuitive. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys relaxing games and studying beautifully rendered backdrops, animals and insects. I'd love to play more of this game if any more content is released in the future, though it's also a game that can be replayed several times for casual gaming.
Very beautiful Bedtime story esque game. Worth playing to relax and the puzzles are an added bonus in what should set the benchmark for discovery and games with a low text requirement.

A maddening game".  They most feedbackyou get is a grating and irritating "dong" when you try to do the wrong the thing. But there is no guide as to what you are supposed to do. Your avatar moves to slowly that you will have to fight the urge to fling your monitor across the room. Additionally
date: it will often decide to move entirely of it's own--you'll click on the image at the bottom of the screen and the game interprets this to mean that you wanted to move your bug to the top--and then locks all control while it sloooooooooooowly transitions to the screen above before you can click (IN THE SAME SPOT!!!) and then wait for it to sloooooooooooowly transition back down again.\n\nWhen I reached a point that nothing I clicked on worked
recommended: and the in-game hint button also "dong"-ed at me
hoursPlayed: I decided I had enough. Save your money."

Morphopholis is a beautifully drawn, slow paced hidden object/puzzle game. The artwork is gorgeous and vibrant - as you can see from the screenshots. There are a few puzzles scattered throughout, each of which are completely different. They aren't too hard, they make sense and some require thinking (if you're not just brute forcing it!). reviewText: nice point and click with good soundtrack and beautiful artstyle, probably most comfortable to play with touchscreen but mouse works ok. quite short, 5 levels each with a few gathering puzzles and 1 or 2 special puzzles. interacting with other living forms in the world reminds me of scribblenauts mechanics a bit.

The game points on the music and the graphic.The music is simply awesome .... this is why I left the intro menu for 10 + minutes even if the tutorial arrow wanted me to click on the first puzzle so badly. The tutorial is short, basicly you have to click everywhere. The thing that is not showed in the short tutorial is that you have different maps and you'll reach them by moving your bug in that direction (sometimes it bugs a bit .... but you know, it's a game of bugs so they wanted friends XD).
The game is quite easy both in the mechanic and game itself but it's still cute and interesting in some of its parts. In 2 hours it was sadly finished.... I want to start it again....
Some puzzles where tricky because you need to use your brain and try to click slide or what else (click and slide stop).
There are no bosses or evil insects here in this game, everything is really peaceful. You climb leaves flowers and insect themselves to help the others with their own issues by clicking the required items to collect them and bring them to the bug in need.
The music is really awesome with the hang drum or pan, but after a while it can be boring if you'll spend a lot of time searching THAT tiny little item that you cannot see.
The morphism of the insect is not an evolution of your starting little bug, as I've thought and maybe you too, but after you finish a level, you'll use a different one.
Overall I love it and I complitely recommend this game, thoug I was hoping it has more than 5 levels Y_Y...

reviewText: Not really worth the full price. Get it cheap, it might be worth your time, but that is a very short time. A good portion of the time I spent in this game, I was distracted texting my girlfriend. It's kinda like a really pretty game of I Spy, but it's really over very quickly, and some of the features aren't very intuitive. For instance, to solve one puzzle you have to collect several of what I assume to be little pebbles of food. To find them,  you have to move your insect to little pods on the branch, and click on your insect to make the green particle thing happen. Either that, or you click (and drag, maybe) on the pods to open them.  Here's the thing that really disappointed me at the end of the game: I found out there was card drops. I have no motivation to play the game to actually collect them! I got one, but I don't even want to play the game again to get the other two, because it's done, there's no more adventure, and I'm just not interested. If you get the game on sale and cheap, fine, play it, enjoy the visuals and music, it's nice. However, other than that it's just not worth it.

Very nice music and atmosphere, but too short.
Also, since there were no instructions in the game itself except hints given sometimes, you may feel too frustrated when you can't figure out how a puzzle works.

...Also.  ._.

I thought that thing in the end  (guess it was a cave or something)  was a  HUMAN.
I thought that bug would transform into a  human  and I was like WOW for a moment.

Was a total disappointment. u.u



-But still!
Puzzles were enjoyable somehow. :3 (Buy that on a discount if you will.)
(I'm also sad that I have no trading cards though the game was over. u.u)

reviewText:
A collection game. Reminds me of what I used to play as a kid in the 90s where you just get given things to look for and they are hidden in places, sometimes in plain sight, and sometimes there is a puzzle you have to figure out to get one of the items.

Enjoyable, though absolutely no replay value and not very challenging; you'll find yourself alt-tabbing and leaving it alone just to rack up enough play time to get the cards after you've completed it.

At ¬£3.99 it's a rip off and the creators should be ashamed of themselves, but for something picked up on the summer sales for 10p it is good.
Rules and Guidelines.
Enjoyable music, gameplay, puzzles, pretty bad control over movement but at sale surely worth of buying. Beside that easy 2h 100% achievements.

I adore this game. It's so pretty! Just a very simple point and click, find the hidden objects type game. Click around the environment to be given objects to find, then once you've found the objects return them and be given a puzzle. If you're stuck, spam the hint button.\n\nI will say that your avatar moves kind of slowly which can get annoying, and that the ending is a bit anticlimatic. I don't care though because it is so beautiful. The objects and the puzzles are really just an excuse to enjoy the scenery. It's kind of psychedelic, kind of surreal...just really gorgeous. A game for those who love their visuals.
Beautiful art, and lovely music. Some of the puzzles are even interesting. The controls are absolutely atrocious, however. clealy poorly translated from mobile platform.

I can't complain since I bought this for 19 cents.  That's basically me selling two steam trading cards.\n\nThe feeling the game gives off... I don't how many of you remember The Very Hungry Caterpillar
date:
but it invokes that same kind of nostalgic blast of color, something that mesmerizes you.  It is more than ten times as bright and vivid as that book, but as adults that's what it takes to overload your senses.  At the same time there is an ever-present sensation of faded-ness.  Like the bright colors are constantly waning and all your efforts is only leading you to the end of both the game and your buggy life.

The game play is nothing special.  It is just a point and click with a few puzzles.

Note:  Screw the beetle lock!  That took me half an hour.  That's 25% of the time spent on this game wasted on a bland rock with five bugs on it!

reviewText: Good game!
THIS GAME TOOK 6 HRS TO GET 3 CARDS
This is an artistic hidden object game, with lots of colors and insects. Its interesting and looks great, but too short.\nNo doubt it was worth the bundle price.

Morphopolis is incredibly beautiful and lush. It is a piece of art teeming with detail and depth. The game, on the other hand, is simple and short. It took me about 2.3 hours to complete all five stages (my additional time played was to get the rest of my card drops). I wouldn't say there is any story in the traditional sense, but there is definitely a depth to the game tapping into the micro/macrocosm that can let the player think about the environment they are playing in or just become immersed in the beautiful backgrounds. The actual puzzles are interesting and varied, but it would have been nice to see more of them per stage. I bought this when it was on sale for 19 cents and it was absolutely worth it. If you are looking for a short point and click-puzzle hybrid, then you should give this a try.
Fun game. Strange/difficult puzzle game. Its a fun play. Beat it in like 2hrs.

Short and sweet with charming visuals and a simple but relaxing soundtrack. Scratches that puzzle solving itch well since there are no hints to help you cheat. Controls however are unresponsive at times which can get frustrating.

In Morphopolis, you never really know what exactly you're looking for or where to find it. But it's a pretty (and short) little puzzle game that will make you look around and explore the jungly bug-land that it's set in. You should be armed with patience, a clever mind, a pair of glasses and a younger sibling/kid to help you out, just in case. (If you have none of those, a cat, an owl or a toad would work, too, I guess.)\n\nI'd say it's worth the 99 cents you'd pay for it (or definitely worth the 33 cents, if you got it on sale). But that's just my opinion.
This is more of a piece of interactive artwork than a game. I got stuck on Level 2. I wasn't clear at all what I had to do.\n\nVisually though, the game is stunning.
This game has beautiful graphics and soothing music. It's a fairly simple point and click hidden object game with a puzzle aspect (nothing too difficult). A quick playthrough but completely worth it!

I absolutely love this game.  It's simple, it's short, and it's very relaxing to play.  I finished the whole thing in one sitting and was left wanting so much more.  While I'm not typically a fan of the find-the-thing game category, this one was beautiful.  It's exotic, innocent, the art is great and the music matches it exquisitely.  I feel like I ripped them off for paying so little.  It's only good for maybe an hour or two of actual play time but good god it's fun while it lasts.  The only downside, and I say this with no disparagement, is that some of the puzzles are not self-evident.  This isn't usually too much of a condemnation except that the game provides virtually no instructions at any point.  Of course, there's Google.  If you're at an absolute loss, do that.  There's a brief how to move sequence at the very beginning and the rest is up for you to figure out.  That being said, just get it.  It's so cheap.  There's really no way to go wrong with this one.  Even if it was just an art and music pack without a game at all it'd still be worthwhile.  If I can pay a dollar for over an hour of childlike wonder then I just won and that's exactly what Morphopolis brings to the table in the most beautiful, multicoloured and delightful way possible.  It's such a beautifully and richly put together game that I can't recommend it enough.

Morphopolis is an art game" if ever there was one.  I say that because I believe for this particular game the art is the priority.  That's not to say there isn't interaction but its gameplay is quite simple.  I'd go as far to say that the gameplay is designed to make sure you focus on and absorb the art.  The eye candy is nice but it takes more then that to design a good game.

In Morphopolis you play as different bugs who are kind enough to help out there neighbors with different chores.   Then at the end of each stage it appears you transfer yourself into a larger bug whom you'll play as in the following stage.  There isn't any written story instead the game leaves it up to you to interrupt the meaning behind you're actions.  Even beyond story-telling there isn't even guides to tell you where to go or what to do.  Restricted movement and actions is enough to let you figure out for yourself what you need to accomplish.

This game is super stylized.  The consistency of the art work between each stage is spot on.  The stages split across multiple screens which connect seamlessly.  The art is this Morphopolis is stunning.  The paintings are incredible and make you really focus when trying to find the objects you need.  You'll be looking at every little detail as your eyes slowly inspect the image.

Essentially
date: this is a find the objects game.  As you play you'll come across particular plants and bugs that stick out from the backgrounds.  Each of them will ask you to find a set amount of particular items for them.  You'll need to carefully scan the backgrounds and gather up all the items.  Then proceed to deliver them in order to clear a path or initiate a special mini-game puzzle.  All the puzzles are very different and I believe this is were Morphopolis loses it consistency.  Until this point the game is fairly easy and relaxing but a couple of the puzzles are incredibly challenging.  This very bizarre difficulty curve takes you out of what is otherwise an immersive and enjoyable game.\n\nVery stylized and original
recommended: the only thing holding this game back from is it's struggle balancing.  If you think this might be a game you'll enjoy don't let that hold you back.  That being said I'm sure some people will really enjoy that added challenge.  Those who are worried about getting frustrated can always minimize the game a bring up walk-through for the really tough puzzles.  As I said before art is at the core of this game.  This is an array of visual stimulation that will let you relax and lose yourself in the world.  Look else where for a more interactive and more traditional "game like" experience."

reviewText: A slow paced click and point puzzle game with mesmerising scenery and relaxing music.

If you like Machinarium or Tiny Bang Story, this game is for you. Kinda similar to these two, but images are very beautiful and different, music is also cute. At first I thought this game is to easy for me, but then I found some places, where I had to think a bit more.\nAnyway, game has cards, cost is pretty small, achievements are not very hard to get, so why not dive in this beautiful small world of flowers and weird bugs.\nWould buy again.

Morphopolis, a beautiful hidden object game.

Pros
The artwork is stunning, as an art piece, this game achieves everything I would want.
The hidden objects are for the most part, fairly easy to indentify. allowing you to take in the artwork
The music slides into the background easily.

Cons
The controls are rough. They work perfectly fine, but many times I found them rather counter-intuitive.
You move painfully slow, and for many of the levels, you need to do a bit of backtracking to find objects previously obscured. Combined, this leads to a very relaxed, and on occasion too relaxed travel time.

Overall, I loved it.
I would definitely recommend it, especially if you enjoy the hidden object genre.

However, if this is going to be your first forey into this style of game, put it on your wishlist, play some of the many more polished, and/or free games that are around. And come back to this one later.

Edit
Seems like the price of the game has changed, and now it actually has a price that seems to fit better the duration of the game, so I decided to change the review to a positive vote instead.

Original Review
I really didn't know if give a thumbs up or thumbs down to this game.

The graphics are awesome, the puzzles are entertaining and the music is very relaxing, it's an awesome game to spend around 2 hours (I finished it in 90 minutes) of relaxing puzzles and really nice looking draws.

However, the game is really expensive considering the small amount of playtime it gives you, either they need to add more levels or you should get it when it's on sale, otherwise stay away from it since it will be money wasted.

The game is awesome, but it's not worth the full price.

This is a very plesant short game. Relaxing music, fun puzzles, very pretty art work and a very reasonable price. The game wasn't too hard but wasn't too easy and really made you think at times. Over all, it is a great game. One thing I really liked about it is how you can get all the achievements from one play through. No need to go through monotonous stuff just to unlock and achievement.\n\nWould I recommend the game? Definitally. The game has been over all a pleasurable experience and missing an oppertunity to play such a beautiful game would be a let down.

Although some may commend it for its beautiful art style; the gameplay is infuriating, unrewarding, and far too slow for me to really appreciate all Morphopolis has to offer. There also isn't a menu where I can tinker with the sounds, which means I have to listen to that annoying bug chirp in the background for the entirety of the game.

The controls are maddening. You click and drag your cursor in the direction that you want the bug to move, but unfortunately the controls don't always work. You'll find yourself dragging, only to watch your bug go back and forth. In certain points, you'll have to wait for an animation to finish until you can move your bug again - which can be upsetting if the controls are screwing up constantly.

There is also tons of backtracking, which makes every level feel tedious. Since every level that you play seems to end with you collecting a serious of orange balls, I know that I am going to have to do that at the end, but I can't collect them all before I receive the quest. Subsequently, I'm forced to backtrack through every single level to collect all of the orange balls in order to go to the next level that will ask me to do the same thing.

Backtracking wouldn't be that much of an issue if your character didn't trek along at the speed of molasses. The two hours that you'll spend completing this game could be cut down to about an hour and half if the bug would move just a tad bit quicker. Unfortunately, that never happens and you're forced to watch your bug move uncomfortably slow through every area - which can be upsetting if you're someone that enjoys gameplay that actually moves at an appropriate pace.

Also, the last puzzle is a treat. By that, I mean, you'll be shouting at your computer screen and wondering why the hell anyone would develop a puzzle as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• as the one you're playing. In the end, Morphopolis is slow, boring, and unrewarding - the gameplay is too little movement, too much grinding and that's just no fun. I cannot recommend this game.

I could pretend to be a connoisseur (I had to look up the spelling) of videogames and use terms like, 'exquisite' and 'impeccable' I'm just a casual gamer, and this was my favourite puzzle game so far. Summary Pretty nice hidden object game with a lovely aesthetic and some decent mini-game puzzles, but with janky controls and a nonexistent story. Worth it at a low price for fans of the genre.

Long story  Morphopolis is a pretty hidden object game. If you do not like hidden object games, do not buy. You play as various iterations of insects that are moving through the world at a very slow pace for‚Ä¶ some reason. As far as I can tell there is no story to the game, just a series of hidden object games and mini-puzzles set in a relatively pretty world. For me that was fine.

My biggest problem with the game was the awful movement controls. You hold down the mouse courser to move instead of just clicking; this results in some awkward dancing and can lead you to incorrectly assume that you cannot move further along a path. The movement is also way too slow and there is no option to double click to change scenes quickly, which artificially prolongs the game by forcing you to crawl back and forth between scenes.

The game also does a relatively poor job of explaining the mini-game puzzle rules as well as some important mechanics which can lead to some frustration. For example you can click on your own character which will is essential to reveal items in some chapters, but as far as I know that is never mentioned in the tutorial.

Still, if you can get it cheap (I got it as part of the art appreciation pack for 0.44 Euro) and you like hidden object games, why not? It‚Äôs not a great game, but it was worth the two hours I spent on it.

The only satisfaction to gain is seeing your insect advance and grow - but it hardly lasts until the end of the game, which was 1.5 hours for me.\nIn a nutshell - short, beautiful and not very enjoyable. reviewText: Gorgeous hand-drawn artwork, atmospheric soothing music and the occasional interesting puzzle does not save this semi-game from ultimately being a very frustrating experience.\n\nI recommend picking this up if you are satisfied with mere artwork and staying far away if you also expect decent gameplay.

This is a cute game where you control various bugs which go around solving puzzles and collecting hidden objects. It looks vaguely like one of those adult colouring in books and has a calming (if somewhat repetitive) Zen-ish soundtrack to go along with it.

The main problem is that the puzzles vary wildly in their difficulty. Some are really easy, like the Memory puzzle with beetles with different numbers of spots on their back or the glowworm pattern repeating puzzle. Others are harder and really difficult to do without a walkthrough, like the petal Draughts and the last Beetle Lock (never doing that again). There are also a few weird bugs (!!) here and there, like when my aphid (part 3 I think?) refused to dissolve the little red balls surrounding the squiggles I had to collect (I prefer to call them squiggles to imagining they're gross maggots or whatever). Like, he would spray his green goop and make his little sucking motion, but he just wouldn't suck up the red balls. Resetting the game entirely and redoing everything he did it fine, but that was really weird and I suspect would have put off someone who does not like wasting their time as much as I do.

It would also be really nice to include colourblind options in this game. A lot of the puzzles really need it (like the beetle lock puzzle) and, besides, it's the year of our luigi 2015 - you should be including colourblind options just by default.

I would tentatively recommend this game, because it's cheap and very pretty. I wouldn't recommend paying more than a dollar or two for it, though.

Ummm.  I guess I'll start with the positives for Morphopolis."  It's graphically well done and pretty.  It's short (2.3 hours).  I bought it dirt cheap ($0.19 instead of its list price of $4.99).  And
date: that's about it.\n\nNow for the negative.  For the most part
hoursPlayed: you usually have no idea what you're supposed to be doing or how to do it.  It's one of those artsy-craftsy games that's exploring the boundaries of gaming.  Hand-in-hand with that
voteText: there is no win state.  You get to the end and say:  "Is that it?" (I actually had to check that I'd got 100% Achievements to figure out that it was over).  And
helpfulPercent: it's SLOW.  You move an insect from screen to screen
votesHelpful: and the game cleverly animates that movement.  At a crawl.  It's and exercise in frustration because you have to crawl from screen to screen over and over again looking for little sprites buried in the scenery.  And
commentsCount: you don't even know if you can quit and save your state.  After an hour of this frustration
column16: I really wanted to put it aside and recover.  But
column17: I was afraid to quit because I was worried I'd have to repeat everything up to that point again.\n\nSo
column18: if you want an "interesting" game with "interesting" art and "interesting" mechanics and can find this at practically nothing
column19: go ahead and buy it.  Otherwise

reviewText: nice point and click with good soundtrack and beautiful artstyle, probably most comfortable to play with touchscreen but mouse works ok. quite short, 5 levels each with a few gathering puzzles and 1 or 2 special puzzles. interacting with other living forms in the world reminds me of scribblenauts mechanics a bit.

The game points on the music and the graphic.The music is simply awesome .... this is why I left the intro menu for 10 + minutes even if the tutorial arrow wanted me to click on the first puzzle so badly. The tutorial is short, basicly you have to click everywhere. The thing that is not showed in the short tutorial is that you have different maps and you'll reach them by moving your bug in that direction (sometimes it bugs a bit .... but you know, it's a game of bugs so they wanted friends XD).
The game is quite easy both in the mechanic and game itself but it's still cute and interesting in some of its parts. In 2 hours it was sadly finished.... I want to start it again....
Some puzzles where tricky because you need to use your brain and try to click slide or what else (click and slide stop).
There are no bosses or evil insects here in this game, everything is really peaceful. You climb leaves flowers and insect themselves to help the others with their own issues by clicking the required items to collect them and bring them to the bug in need.
The music is really awesome with the hang drum or pan, but after a while it can be boring if you'll spend a lot of time searching THAT tiny little item that you cannot see.
The morphism of the insect is not an evolution of your starting little bug, as I've thought and maybe you too, but after you finish a level, you'll use a different one.
Overall I love it and I complitely recommend this game, thoug I was hoping it has more than 5 levels Y_Y...

reviewText: I can't complain since I bought this for 19 cents.  That's basically me selling two steam trading cards.\n\nThe feeling the game gives off... I don't how many of you remember The Very Hungry Caterpillar
date:
but it invokes that same kind of nostalgic blast of color, something that mesmerizes you.  It is more than ten times as bright and vivid as that book, but as adults that's what it takes to overload your senses.  At the same time there is an ever-present sensation of faded-ness.  Like the bright colors are constantly waning and all your efforts is only leading you to the end of both the game and your buggy life.

The game play is nothing special.  It is just a point and click with a few puzzles.

Note:  Screw the beetle lock!  That took me half an hour.  That's 25% of the time spent on this game wasted on a bland rock with five bugs on it!

reviewText: Simple and quick game for people who love passing the time with a quiet game. If you like hidden objects and puzzle games, then I recommend this. Ended sooner than I thought it would and it would be better if it had a huge more stages/levels.

Morphopolis is a beautiful and very short hidden-object game with some puzzles of various levels of difficulty. There is no real story, but rather a sequence of scenes that more-or-less overlap with an insect's life.

As you can see from the screenshots, it is a delight to behold! Just be aware that, unfortunately, it is also frustrating to play: the controls are terrible, as you move very slowly and it's too easy to move to the next screen by mistake. Luckily, the game is short enough that the frustration will soon end.

Also, note that the final puzzle is devilishly hard. Because it's randomized, there is no single walkthrough that would work for everyone. You have to understand it the old-fashioned way and patiently figure it out!
Glorified Hidden Object Game with fetch quests for work-shy insects.\nIt looks adorable, but there's only 1,5hr of content. I spent the other 1,5 hour trying to do the last ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing puzzle.

Oh yeah, its pretty and amazing and I napped to the music on puzzles that took me a bit long. Made for a relaxing night. When played on a touchscreen, its great to rub your little buggy face. The movement speed may be slow but it would only be a problem if the game was any longer. I thought it was nice to slow down for a little while. It was great until the puzzle at the end. It's short and super artsy. Pretty repetitive gameplay, but since it's short it doesn't have time to wear you down. It's really about exploring the area and admiring all the stuff around you. The puzzles are not terribly difficult (except the last one, which is just frustrating), but the lack of instruction in a lot of them meant that one or two took me a few minutes before I even found the controls.

For the money it's a nice game to keep you busy for a few hours. The game is very soothing and has a great artstyle and relaxing music. The puzzles are quite simple, except for the last one: that one was really a living hell for me. But still a great game, especially for the low price.

Morphopolis is incredibly beautiful and lush. It is a piece of art teeming with detail and depth. The game, on the other hand, is simple and short. It took me about 2.3 hours to complete all five stages (my additional time played was to get the rest of my card drops). I wouldn't say there is any story in the traditional sense, but there is definitely a depth to the game tapping into the micro/macrocosm that can let the player think about the environment they are playing in or just become immersed in the beautiful backgrounds. The actual puzzles are interesting and varied, but it would have been nice to see more of them per stage. I bought this when it was on sale for 19 cents and it was absolutely worth it. If you are looking for a short point and click-puzzle hybrid, then you should give this a try.

reviewText: Fun game. Strange/difficult puzzle game. Its a fun play. Beat it in like 2hrs.

In Morphopolis, you never really know what exactly you're looking for or where to find it. But it's a pretty (and short) little puzzle game that will make you look around and explore the jungly bug-land that it's set in. You should be armed with patience, a clever mind, a pair of glasses and a younger sibling/kid to help you out, just in case. (If you have none of those, a cat, an owl or a toad would work, too, I guess.)\n\nI'd say it's worth the 99 cents you'd pay for it (or definitely worth the 33 cents, if you got it on sale). But that's just my opinion.

While this game is very short (I completed it in under two hours without any guides or walkthroughs), it has a gorgeous sense of style and the puzzles are fun and intuitive. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys relaxing games and studying beautifully rendered backdrops, animals and insects. Would I recommend this game? Whenever the price drops for a while again, then yes, especially if you feel charmed by the look of the game. However everything above 2 Euro would seem too much pricy n my opinion... Here's why:

Pro:
* the artful drawings and likable meditation-inducing piano-sound give off a very nice and enjoyable atmosphere
* this game is in reality a Hidden Object Game - search for half-hidden stuff in 2D-sceneries filled to the rim with details and in between play a number of different minigames. Which is great in my opinion because I love HOGs. Well, if you don't, that might not be a Plus for you then...
* if you have ever played a bunch of HOGs, you will immediately recognize the minigames and will know what you have to do, as they are all very typical and not too hard to solve
* Morphopolis also has elements of an adventure as you have to control" an insect and make it crawl around a bit plus you'll have to click on some cratures or plants to "hand in" stuff you've found/collected. But this is very little adventure-like gameplay all in all

This is how you elevate a game above most others in its genre.\n\nA standard point-and-click puzzle/hidden object game, except with superb visuals and an interesting world to navigate. The game is simple (uncomplicated), yet somewhat challenging with some of the puzzles. The appeal of the unique surroundings is enough to keep me interested in playing, but the actual gameplay is also very good.

Morphopolis knows what it wants to do.  Provide a game that runs off the player's curiosity, and provide a few simple puzzles for the player to figure out on their own.  I love how it had no dialogue, leaving me to try and figure out what the heck I was doing for most of the time.  Though it's controls are restricted to the mouse, the game still feels like the antithesis of a lot of modern games, and feels like it pays tribute to an era lost in gaming where hand holding wasn't mandatory.

Pros

Very pleasing asthetic.  From what I understand, it was hand-drawn, and looked very good.  A lot of life from a soft palette, and I didn't feel like any problematic circumstances were due to the visuals.

Again, I had a lot of freedom (even though the gameplay was technically on rails) to explore and tackle the puzzles as they came.  You don't see that often nowadays.

Cons

The music was a bit of a wash.  My experience only lasted about an hour and a half, but most of the music is just some percussion and a xylophone - which wasn't as immersive when it hasn't noticibly changed 80% through the game.  I think there were other types of music at the start of the levels, but they inevitably sounded the same.

My Verdict

I think anyone who is considering buying this should understand what it was made for - a brief session of immersive puzzle solving in a visualy pleasing art style.  I personally, enjoyed my experience with it (where others clearly have not).  It's short, sweet, and - though I don't think of it as a particularly memorable experience - believe it was worth my time.

I felt compelled to check out this game when it was on sale for $.19, because how could such a beautiful looking puzzler be only $.19? I'm so glad I did. This is a very small, quirky game, but it's a beautiful little gem well worth your time.

The music and hand-drawn insect and nature art create a very peaceful, otherworldly atmosphere to explore. There are no words or text instructions, but the game has a hint button which will highlight your next step if you can't figure out what to do next. Gameplay is basically hidden item-gathering exploration, interspersed with a puzzle in each chapter. The game progresses in a way that feels natural to understand. The puzzles can be tricky, but not impossible, and everything about the game is satisfying when you figure things out on your own. That said, if you get totally stuck on a puzzle and need a nudge in the right direction, check out the excellent Steam guides people have written.

Some caveats: There are five chapters, and if you close the game in the middle of a chapter, you'll have to start from the beginning of that chapter again. I can't find this as a flaw since the chapters take so little time to complete (you can finish the game with all achievements in 2-3 hours), but it's something to know before you play.

You also can't close the game during a puzzle, but again, most of them don't take very long to solve. One reviewer complained that puzzles have no reset button if you mess them up, but none of them can be messed up except the chapter 4 puzzle, which does have a reset button (the yellow spot on the right of the puzzle).

This is a very small, lovely little world to spend a couple of hours in, and I recommend it.

You just have to relax and imagine you're exploring a new world and take it as it comes.  If you're completely stuck, there is help to find the hidden items but the puzzles just have to be solved.  Great deal for the quality!

reviewText: A view from different insect's perspectives and some interesting puzzle games!

It's short and super artsy. Pretty repetitive gameplay, but since it's short it doesn't have time to wear you down. It's really about exploring the area and admiring all the stuff around you. The puzzles are not terribly difficult (except the last one, which is just frustrating), but the lack of instruction in a lot of them meant that one or two took me a few minutes before I even found the controls.

Morphopolis is an atmospheric game where you partially control an insect in an environment, collecting specific items by clicking on them, somewhat reminiscient of those old I Spy games. I certainly had a bit of a nostalgia hard-on while playing this game, full disclaimer on that one.

I'd certainly say Morphopolis is quite therapeutic (unless you hate bugs), it has calming music, a vibrant environment that somehow feels huge, empty, and filled to the brim at the same time through its artistic use of the whole bug-world. There are plenty of times where you'll feel like the game is moving way too slow, and you will be stumped heavily on a puzzle or two here and there, perhaps to a point of rage, but in the end it makes you feel more accomplished. There even is a noticable progression between levels which gives you an air on familiarity in a new, strange environment.

In the end, the game doesn't take too long to beat. But the apprehension and depiction of the whole game makes it feel longer, it gives you a feeling of being accomplished and completed. It's not a wonderful, 10/10 game, but for someone who's willing to take the time and mild frustration to complete the game, it can be a nice gaming/art experience.

Is ok.

This game is odd, but in a good way.

I can't tell what it's trying to be; whether it's a child's game, with dark, underlying themes, or whether it's an adventure into a mystical world just below normal human perception. But whatever it is, it's incredible. The puzzles were mostly easy (with the exception of the trickier final puzzle) and the gameplay was point and click, which searching aspects. But this, for me, was less of a game, and more of an experience. The art was absolutely awesome, and gave the world a unique and intriguing twist I haven't seen in a story game before.

Should you buy it? That depends. If you're the kind of person who sits down for five minutes, leaves, and comes back, don't buy this. But if you like to take your time, and involve yourself in a game, this story without words would appeal to you like no other.

The soundtrack made me just sit down and listen to the music, while the screen displayed just a menu, for about five minutes before starting the game. Each environment gave me a new sense of accomplishment, and I just look back on it and smile. That is, until I play it again.

It is a short game, but it will change you.

I spent quite a bit of time working on a chapter, then exited figuring it would save my progress just as any other HOG does, and when I came back I was back to the beginning of the chapter. Very frustrating. So, for a pretty HOG it‚Äôs good but for a game which is supposed to be relaxing, it is more irritating than anything.

Edit
Seems like the price of the game has changed, and now it actually has a price that seems to fit better the duration of the game, so I decided to change the review to a positive vote instead.

Morphopolis is a very interesting, and unique game that takes place in the world of insects. There are very few games of this variety. At first glance you might think that this is just an artificial life simulator type of game (Examples of such games are Simlife, Simant, and Spore). But, you would be wrong. Because this is actually a 2D, point and click game with puzzles (LOTS of them to say the least). You start the game off by playing as a caterpillar, and you must help the caterpillar create a cocoon in order to proceed to the next level. Don't start thinking that you'll play as a caterpillar in every level, there actually are other insects in this game you can play as later on. Don't worry, I won't give away the names of the other insects or describe their appearances (assuming you're a gamer who likes surprises). There are puzzles in every level of Morphopolis. A puzzle can be accessed by collecting a certain amount of items (Sticks, berries, pollen, etc.). Some puzzles are easily solved in a matter of minutes, while others will have you leaning your head against your hand wondering how on earth you can find a solution to the current puzzle. The artwork in this game is absolutely beautiful. But the animation is somewhat cheap (Seems like the kind of animation you'd see in a Newgrounds game). Now as for the soundtrack, it's very atmospheric, and fits the game like a glove. The only complaint I have with this game is that it's too short! I managed to complete this game in a single day (I'm not kidding). Partly because the puzzles in this game are very similar to puzzles I've seen in other games. Now if you're a casual gamer, then chances are you're probably going to be playing this game much longer then I would. Overall, Morphopolis is a very well designed game that I wish could have a sequel or an expansion pack. If you like Professor Layton or any other puzzle game in general, give this one a try.

In five levels you take control of an insect trying to get to the end of the level but a row of obstacles get in your way. To get rid of them you need to solve a few puzzles or find a certain amount of objects (which is more challenging than it sounds considering the detailed backgrounds you have to look at to find the objects).

What's nice is that the game is quite relaxing which is because of the soothing easy-listening soundtrack and the design which make you feel you're in some sort of jungle right now.

You won't get any help in the game on what a puzzle is about but most of the time it's easy to find out. Only the very last puzzle in level 5 is very tricky.

reviewText:
This game is actually really interesting. It‚Äôs a beautiful piece of art with high details and bright colors. No, I am not talking about a painting; I‚Äôm talking about the game although the game is like a painting in a way. It has a very calming feel that helps you relax as you try to work out the puzzles and find the items in which you‚Äôre looking for. It‚Äôs a very short game, only about an hour or two depending on how good you are at puzzles and hidden object games. Behind the puzzles and artwork, we have an interesting sort of story that is abstract enough for you to take what you want from it. It is one of those games that might have a deeper meaning if you really want to look for it.

They don‚Äôt really explain a story line for the game much, you are thrust straight into the game as a little larva or caterpillar wiggling around. It keeps you in that insect world as you go from a small larva to a grasshopper to a bee and so on. There aren‚Äôt any times that you actually fly or jump which is kind of strange but you walk around gathering items and the end of the stage is crawling into what looks like a carcass of the bug you will be next. I know the game is called morphopolis and is supposed to be about metamorphosis but this feels more like you taking over the dead bug instead.

The game play is‚Ä¶ at times its pretty good when you get into the puzzles but the movement of the character walking around is a little hard to deal with. Times when I am clicking to find the objects, the little character that I was playing would move and go into a different scene when I am not ready for it. That‚Äôs the problem with clicking the screen being both for finding items and moving your character. There are times when my character also had trouble finding the pathways I wanted him to go on.  I think it would have been a bit easier if they had the arrow keys to move the character as I could hit the down button or up to go on those paths. The character moves very slowly which can make that part of the game boring when you have to go back and forward to collect items. There is a lot of back tracking in this and it would have been nice to be able to have the character speed up. There is one other problem that I do have with the puzzles. The puzzles don‚Äôt tell you how to do them, you sort of just have to try different things to figure it out. There was one puzzle I got stuck on because nothing I did was actually working that I had to look up what the puzzle was supposed to be so I could play it.

The artwork is so amazing. It‚Äôs very high detail and is almost like a surreal painting with how playful the colors and designs are. The problem with this though is that there are times you can‚Äôt find the path you need to go on most of the time. The paths just blend in with the background or are really hard to figure out. They luckily have it so that when you click your character, a couple green sparkles will resonate from him and travel a little way along the path though sometimes its hard to see depending on how high detailed the area is around them. On the other hand, the high detail does make finding the objects your looking for all the more rewarding as it is hard to see them.

The music is so calming and a little mysterious. There is one track through the whole thing and yet I never got bored of it. It‚Äôs a piano solo that almost put me to sleep a couple of times during the long walk parts. That is all I can really say on it as its just calming.

Overall, it was a nice little game to play. Is it worth the money that it is on steam right now? Maybe not. I got the game on a steam sale and It was worth the amount I paid for but I‚Äôm not sure if it‚Äôs the full $4.99 worth. My recommendation is to get it on sale because it is a good game, and it is beautiful. If you get it for the normal price, then you‚Äôre mostly paying for the artwork.

A hidden object puzzle game with no text, so you can play even if you don't speak English. No text = no tutorials or instructions, but the puzzles are straightforward enough that figuring out what you're supposed to do feels like part of the gameplay rather than a roadblock.\n\nGorgeous art and music make me forgive Morphopolis's faults -- primarily lack of a save function and poor movement controls.

An interesting Hidden Object style game, though not one that's easy to recommend.
The longer you play for, the more the small things irritate you. Like having to wait while your bug crawls ever-so-slowly across the screen to move to a new area, it's a dreadful new way of padding-out a game's length. If moving between screens was simply a matter of clicking arrows (like in most other HOG's) then you'd finish it 66% faster than it actually takes.
If you're short of patience i imagine it will drive you up the wall.

Also there is a lack of explanation for some of the puzzles leaving you clicking randomly all over the place until something changes and you can see what you're supposed to be doing.

It's not worth full-price but if you're a die-hard Hidden Object fan then pick it up in a sale.

Either that, or you click (and drag, maybe) on the pods to open them.  Here's the thing that really disappointed me at the end of the game: I found out there was card drops. I have no motivation to play the game to actually collect them! I got one, but I don't even want to play the game again to get the other two, because it's done, there's no more adventure, and I'm just not interested. If you get the game on sale and cheap, fine, play it, enjoy the visuals and music, it's nice. However, other than that it's just not worth it.
