Morphopolis is a very casual game. I got it on sale a while back. I will tell you why I did not think it was worth even that price.

You play as a bug growing and changing along the way at the same pace of something very slow. Really, really slow. Even animations would take their time. I would say if the movement and animation was not so slow, I would be able to finish it in half the time it took me. Probably even less, I did AFK for a little. Moving the bug around also sucked. Sometimes it would go in one direction or the other. Accidentally moving to another scene/area happened often.

Personally, I found the music in Morphopolis okay. Not terrible at all.

The puzzles, as some people stated, can be hard. I did not have a ton of difficulty myself, but others were annoyed that there is no reset button.

Although I thought the game looked nice, the art style made it hard to see what I had to do. This game might be hard for someone that had a colour blindness. OR maybe not, I am not colour blind. I cannot say for sure.

So the game design isn't super great. Going through the menus and not understanding what the buttons did could be my fault. I accidentally went back to the menu in the middle of a level. I don't believe that there will be updates in the future to fix/change anything.

I do not think I will ever replay this game. Going through the levels and puzzles will just annoy me again. I am not saying you cannot replay it, but there will not be anything you missed the first time. Unless there is some easter egg I am not aware of.

If you like art" you will probably like this game. Or if you like casual
date: slow paced game play. But not too casual because you will have a hard time finding the hidden object. Do you also love puzzles? Hard puzzles? Music? Sound effects? Bad menus? Little to no directions? Slow motion creepy crawlies? Then you should definitely get this game when it's on sale."

Morphopolis is a beautiful and very short hidden-object game with some puzzles of various levels of difficulty. There is no real story, but rather a sequence of scenes that more-or-less overlap with an insect's life.

As you can see from the screenshots, it is a delight to behold! Just be aware that, unfortunately, it is also frustrating to play: the controls are terrible, as you move very slowly and it's too easy to move to the next screen by mistake. Luckily, the game is short enough that the frustration will soon end.

Also, note that the final puzzle is devilishly hard. Because it's randomized, there is no single walkthrough that would work for everyone. You have to understand it the old-fashioned way and patiently figure it out!

At the last puzzle I was sure that I wouldn't be able to solve It without any help...\n\nIt is a nice slow paced atmospheric game. It has a very unexpected storyline (I think It is a storyline). And It's soundtrack decent too. One level had a melancholic tune and I just got lost in that tune at least for 15 minutes.And It's really cheap too.

reviewText:
This game works much better as art than it does a game, but it does have some game elements.

The main themes the game uses is point-and-click collecting of items on the screen, in addition to the occasional mini-game. It's fairly casual, and might take you a few hours to complete the game. There's no central story that I remember picking up on. Each level follows a different bug that you control, moving around several maps to collect items.

Don't expect a whole lot from this game; it's very clear that most of the work went into the graphics, so expect vibrant graphics and basic functionality. I would personally recommend waiting for the game to go under $1 before buying.

Yes, I'd recommend it. But with a big but. I'd recommend buying it only on a sale (as I did); The game is extremely short and 1.6 hours Steam registred I played to beat 5 chapters should be about it (at least if I haven't screw something fircely and didn't see another whole act of the game, but I doubt it (...checked with howlongtobeat and yeah, there's nothing else after five chapters).\nYes, the art is extraordinary, the gentle music and subtle animations make for a very pleasant zen experience, but I'd like a bit more to it. Nevertheless, apart from very slow walking animation (if it were as it should be for an insect crawling speed, the game would be at least some 10 min shorter...) those were 1.6 hours I enjoyed. At the time of writing, it's on -96% off and I don't see a reason not to. For a full price? Should be a bit longer..

So, I bought this game on sale for it's visual presentation, and in that area I was not dissapointed; the game is beautiful and does a fantastic job of making you feel like you are in the pages of a storybook. The game itself has some hiccups to work through, though.

First of all, the game was designed for a touch screen, and it shows. The all mouse interface is functional, but not ideal. While finding things through the world is fine, the use of the mouse for movement is clunky and can definitely start to grate after a while, especially as you slowly move up and down and back and forth across the levels. Some of the puzzles likewise feel a bit clunky which can push a challenging puzzle over the brink into frustrating. The puzzles themselves are fine, nothing too wild and probably variations of things you've seen before. That's not bad, just know that it's nothing groundbreaking.

The game itself is made up of I spy hunts for various items, puzzles, and the occasional interaction with the environment. Again, nothing earth shattering, but functional enough to keep things interesting. Most of the gameplay is made up of hunting for the items on the screen with puzzles being the reward for finding them. Again, these aren't bad things, but don't expect an insect version of Broken Sword.

The game is definitely worth playing if you find the art style intriguing. That's what drew me in, and it definitely delivered on that count. The gameplay is nothing to write home about, but with the art and presentation draped over it, it works.

Morphopolis is an atmospheric game where you partially control an insect in an environment, collecting specific items by clicking on them, somewhat reminiscient of those old I Spy games. I certainly had a bit of a nostalgia hard-on while playing this game, full disclaimer on that one.

I'd certainly say Morphopolis is quite therapeutic (unless you hate bugs), it has calming music, a vibrant environment that somehow feels huge, empty, and filled to the brim at the same time through its artistic use of the whole bug-world. There are plenty of times where you'll feel like the game is moving way too slow, and you will be stumped heavily on a puzzle or two here and there, perhaps to a point of rage, but in the end it makes you feel more accomplished. There even is a noticable progression between levels which gives you an air on familiarity in a new, strange environment.

In the end, the game doesn't take too long to beat. But the apprehension and depiction of the whole game makes it feel longer, it gives you a feeling of being accomplished and completed. It's not a wonderful, 10/10 game, but for someone who's willing to take the time and mild frustration to complete the game, it can be a nice gaming/art experience.

Is ok.

This game is odd, but in a good way.

I can't tell what it's trying to be; whether it's a child's game, with dark, underlying themes, or whether it's an adventure into a mystical world just below normal human perception. But whatever it is, it's incredible. The puzzles were mostly easy (with the exception of the trickier final puzzle) and the gameplay was point and click, which searching aspects. But this, for me, was less of a game, and more of an experience. The art was absolutely awesome, and gave the world a unique and intriguing twist I haven't seen in a story game before.

Should you buy it? That depends. If you're the kind of person who sits down for five minutes, leaves, and comes back, don't buy this. But if you like to take your time, and involve yourself in a game, this story without words would appeal to you like no other.

The soundtrack made me just sit down and listen to the music, while the screen displayed just a menu, for about five minutes before starting the game. Each environment gave me a new sense of accomplishment, and I just look back on it and smile. That is, until I play it again.

It is a short game, but it will change you.

reviewText: Morphopolis has some nice artwork but suffers from terrible usability issues.\n\nGameplay is Hidden Object" clicking; the objects are usually not very hidden at all
date:
but they are progress-gated so that you cannot click on them until the game lets you.

Character movement is a nightmare. The game forces you to backtrack and just walking from screen to screen feels like a battle of wills.

A fullscreen puzzle on level 4 (flower pollen) cannot be exited without force-quitting the game and provides so little feedback that it caused an immediate flurry of users begging the devs to fix it upon release; over six months later there have been no updates.

I cannot recommend this at any price in its current state."

reviewText: Very pretty game, though I have to admit some of the end level puzzles were hard to figure out what to do with no hints or anything.

What can I say about the game ? This game is about a caterpillar and it tries to survive and solve puzzles . The game makes you wonder about insects ! After all, they too are living beings ! A funny game !
only if you need cards...
A slow paced click and point puzzle game with mesmerising scenery and relaxing music.

Morphopolis is an art game" if ever there was one.  I say that because I believe for this particular game the art is the priority.  That's not to say there isn't interaction but its gameplay is quite simple.  I'd go as far to say that the gameplay is designed to make sure you focus on and absorb the art.  The eye candy is nice but it takes more then that to design a good game.

In Morphopolis you play as different bugs who are kind enough to help out there neighbors with different chores.   Then at the end of each stage it appears you transfer yourself into a larger bug whom you'll play as in the following stage.  There isn't any written story instead the game leaves it up to you to interrupt the meaning behind you're actions.  Even beyond story-telling there isn't even guides to tell you where to go or what to do.  Restricted movement and actions is enough to let you figure out for yourself what you need to accomplish.

This game is super stylized.  The consistency of the art work between each stage is spot on.  The stages split across multiple screens which connect seamlessly.  The art is this Morphopolis is stunning.  The paintings are incredible and make you really focus when trying to find the objects you need.  You'll be looking at every little detail as your eyes slowly inspect the image.

Essentially
date: this is a find the objects game.  As you play you'll come across particular plants and bugs that stick out from the backgrounds.  Each of them will ask you to find a set amount of particular items for them.  You'll need to carefully scan the backgrounds and gather up all the items.  Then proceed to deliver them in order to clear a path or initiate a special mini-game puzzle.  All the puzzles are very different and I believe this is were Morphopolis loses it consistency.  Until this point the game is fairly easy and relaxing but a couple of the puzzles are incredibly challenging.  This very bizarre difficulty curve takes you out of what is otherwise an immersive and enjoyable game.\n\nVery stylized and original
recommended: the only thing holding this game back from is it's struggle balancing.  If you think this might be a game you'll enjoy don't let that hold you back.  That being said I'm sure some people will really enjoy that added challenge.  Those who are worried about getting frustrated can always minimize the game a bring up walk-through for the really tough puzzles.  As I said before art is at the core of this game.  This is an array of visual stimulation that will let you relax and lose yourself in the world.  Look else where for a more interactive and more traditional "game like" experience."

a below 5$ must play game!

Morphopolis, a beautiful hidden object game.

Pros
The artwork is stunning, as an art piece, this game achieves everything I would want.
The hidden objects are for the most part, fairly easy to indentify. allowing you to take in the artwork
The music slides into the background easily.

Cons
The controls are rough. They work perfectly fine, but many times I found them rather counter-intuitive.
You move painfully slow, and for many of the levels, you need to do a bit of backtracking to find objects previously obscured. Combined, this leads to a very relaxed, and on occasion too relaxed travel time.

Overall, I loved it.
I would definitely recommend it, especially if you enjoy the hidden object genre.

However, if this is going to be your first forey into this style of game, put it on your wishlist, play some of the many more polished, and/or free games that are around. And come back to this one later.

Morphopolis is a game that takes you through different transformations. You play as a variety of insects that collect different parts to evolve. Very colorful and great scenery. Recommended for those who like hidden object, and challenging puzzle games.

I loved this game. It was beautiful to look at and the music was calming. Some of the puzzles are tricky, especially the beetle puzzle on level 5. Once I finished the beetle puzzle, I was actually a little sad because I wanted the game to go on longer.

This game has beautiful graphics and soothing music. It's a fairly simple point and click hidden object game with a puzzle aspect (nothing too difficult). A quick playthrough but completely worth it!

The game has very nice, psychedelic-esque graphics and the puzzles are of mildly difficultly. But on the down side the game-play is a bit boring - the insect (your character) moves really, really slow. So, to enjoy the game to it's fullest, I'd recommend getting high. ^^

I absolutely love this game.  It's simple, it's short, and it's very relaxing to play.  I finished the whole thing in one sitting and was left wanting so much more.  While I'm not typically a fan of the find-the-thing game category, this one was beautiful.  It's exotic, innocent, the art is great and the music matches it exquisitely.  I feel like I ripped them off for paying so little.  It's only good for maybe an hour or two of actual play time but good god it's fun while it lasts.  The only downside, and I say this with no disparagement, is that some of the puzzles are not self-evident.  This isn't usually too much of a condemnation except that the game provides virtually no instructions at any point.  Of course, there's Google.  If you're at an absolute loss, do that.  There's a brief how to move sequence at the very beginning and the rest is up for you to figure out.  That being said, just get it.  It's so cheap.  There's really no way to go wrong with this one.  Even if it was just an art and music pack without a game at all it'd still be worthwhile.  If I can pay a dollar for over an hour of childlike wonder then I just won and that's exactly what Morphopolis brings to the table in the most beautiful, multicoloured and delightful way possible.  It's such a beautifully and richly put together game that I can't recommend it enough.

reviewText:
This is a really neat game. Quite short unfortunately, but if you see it on a sale for approx $.20, it's definetly worth it.

Controls are a bit glitchy, but after a while you are able to overcome any imperfections.

Beautifull and relaxing, mmm,,, maybe it's even more more better playing when you on trip ha ha ha ha,,,,

Morphopolis is incredibly beautiful and lush. It is a piece of art teeming with detail and depth. The game, on the other hand, is simple and short. It took me about 2.3 hours to complete all five stages (my additional time played was to get the rest of my card drops). I wouldn't say there is any story in the traditional sense, but there is definitely a depth to the game tapping into the micro/macrocosm that can let the player think about the environment they are playing in or just become immersed in the beautiful backgrounds. The actual puzzles are interesting and varied, but it would have been nice to see more of them per stage. I bought this when it was on sale for 19 cents and it was absolutely worth it. If you are looking for a short point and click-puzzle hybrid, then you should give this a try.

Oh wonderful, a glitchy find an object game for 5 god damn dollars.\n\n11/10

I can't complain since I bought this for 19 cents.  That's basically me selling two steam trading cards.\n\nThe feeling the game gives off... I don't how many of you remember The Very Hungry Caterpillar
date:
but it invokes that same kind of nostalgic blast of color, something that mesmerizes you.  It is more than ten times as bright and vivid as that book, but as adults that's what it takes to overload your senses.  At the same time there is an ever-present sensation of faded-ness.  Like the bright colors are constantly waning and all your efforts is only leading you to the end of both the game and your buggy life.

The game play is nothing special.  It is just a point and click with a few puzzles.

Note:  Screw the beetle lock!  That took me half an hour.  That's 25% of the time spent on this game wasted on a bland rock with five bugs on it!

reviewText: Can't reset puzzles (last one is random), slow paced and no exit buton. Apart from the atmosphere and music, this game didn't gave me any positive feelings, only frustrations.\nMuie/ 10.

reviewText: In Morphopolis, you never really know what exactly you're looking for or where to find it. But it's a pretty (and short) little puzzle game that will make you look around and explore the jungly bug-land that it's set in. You should be armed with patience, a clever mind, a pair of glasses and a younger sibling/kid to help you out, just in case. (If you have none of those, a cat, an owl or a toad would work, too, I guess.)\n\nI'd say it's worth the 99 cents you'd pay for it (or definitely worth the 33 cents, if you got it on sale). But that's just my opinion.
